												Waaay too grindy without nearly enough variety in the levels. The rooms all seem super flat wtihout any variety in height. I remember classic gauntlet games had waterfalls, sprawling valleys, immense wooden towers, human slaughterhouses, cryptic collectables, several diverse bosses, familiars, the circus of the damned, hell, graveyards, plains saturated in green vomitous zepplin filth, caves, cooperative attacks, the list goes on and on.All that's left is *kill 1000 enemies and you'll do five percent more damage* bonuses that rehash the gameplay as poorly as killing floor, alongside what feels like no variety in the dungeons.Worst part is every level wtih death chasing you the graphics go haywire and artifacts make it impossible to see. No other game I play does that so I'm thinking it's not my video card.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												As you can see, I recommend this game, but it comes with a few caveats.If you're wanting an experience similar to the classic Gauntlet games, or even like the newer 3D versions like Dark Legacy, this is probably not the game you're looking for. You want to go look at Hammerwatch instead. Trust me.That's not to say this is a bad game, but it has a lot of short comings, and many gameplay elements of Gauntlet have been dropped, some new ones added, and it just doesn't really feel like the Gauntlet I grew up with. Which to be fair, is one of my favorite games of all time. Both the classic versions and the 3D ones.Dungeon floors aren't randomized, and while I know this wasn't a feature in the other games in this series, in the current game market this just feels lazy. I'm already getting sick of running the same (very few) levels over and over with the only change being which character I play as. Secrets and the like are also mysteriously lacking.We might as well talk about those characters, actually. Each one plays differently, and not just in regard to how they attack or what skills they use. They fundamentally control different from each other. The Wizard, for instance, mixes two elements together to create one of a number of spells. The Elf plays similar to a twin stick shooter character, akin to Smash TV or Beat Hazard. The Warrior and Valkyrie are kind of similar, but the Valkyrie has the ability to tank, and defend the party with her shield.She's also very overpowered compared to the other characters (in my opinion at least) once you learn to use her effectively. A lot of people don't even play her as a tank, and instead spear rush nonstop, which does a lot of damage very quickly. This makes it easy to lead a game in points from having a really high kill score compared to the other players. This is especially true if they haven't learned how to use their character yet.Each character also has a set of challenges that come with them, which unlock little passive buffs when you complete them. Kill 2000 mummies, get +10% damage against them. Things like this. Progress is not shared across characters, so if you have been mainly playing as one class, then join a multiplayer game where that class is already taken, you'll be missing all the unlocked bonuses for that character, as well as any relics they have bought. There are a couple minor bugs and AI quirks (enemies can't walk under bridges that are on a higher level than them?), but nothing that is a huge issue. I've only had one instance of the game bugging out and putting me in a state where I could not progress because of a gate not opening as it should have.It's a co-op game, but not really. What I mean is that it is in your best interest (even if it's not the parties best interest) to hog everything for yourself, let other people die so you can steal the gold they drop, and generally act like an ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ to people you don't know.  While I really don't have a problem with the game allowing that, it has never been how I played Gauntlet with my friends. You always do a lot better if you work as a damn team, even if your score won't be as high from being selfish. Joining online games is a real chore, and it usually takes me upwards of ten attempts before it finally joins a game without either giving me a timeout error or saying the game is already full.There's no way to communicate with the other players, outside of four nearly useless emotes that are mapped to the D-pad.  Maybe this was the intent, but when I can just shift+tab to talk to the people via Steam's built in chat, this just feels like an oversight and creates an extra step (and one that takes me out of the game) to offer advice. The biggest problem with not being able to communicate, to me at least, is that it is really bothersome to try to figure out which level everyone wants to do when starting a multiplayer game. Again, this isn't a bad game, but if you really want something like Gauntlet, go pick up Hammerwatch instead. Otherwise, I'd really wait for a sale for this one.

content:
Posted: September 29, 2014
												An excellent homage to the old school arcade game, this reiteration plays exactly like you would expect. You have four characters, each with their own skills and abilities, and you team up with friends to obliterate huge waves of enemies, all while splitting up (or fighting over) the spoils. The voice acting is very witty and entertaining for all the characters, and each character has "masteries" which you unlock by doing certain things in game, such as killing x amount of a certain monster, or even dying multiple times on a level. These masteries unlock subtle but useful passive abilities on that character, such as slightly increased damage, or a longer spawn protection. While rather linear, this is a great dungeon crawler game, especially with friends. And at a modest price of $20 (like Torchlight II), you can't go wrong.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
												I do love the game.  While the fun hack and slash co-op feel of the original is wonderfully preserved, the new reboot adds new depth through diversifying the playstyles of the classes.  The in-game interaction between the 4 heroes who are old friends (since 1985) is endearing and nostalgic, the music and stages are beautiful.  Controls feel nice and fluid, and the difficulty levels are well balanced.  While many of the negative reviews are true (ie: short content, lack of communication features, need for better matchmaking), the developers of the game do monitor the forums for feedback. Bottom line is: it is great fun, and there's more to come.Edit (Dec 1, 2014): as of this edit, patch 1.04 had gone live, improving many features such as the matchmaking, in-game communication, and rebalancing the classes.  I recommend the game even more highly now.

number of helpful: 5 of 9 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												The nostalgia is strong with this one, I was ten years old in 1985 & my favourite game at the local Arcades was Gauntlet. I played this to death with my friends and this remake does the original justice. Another game from the same era was Smash TV, it involved kiting yourself around avoiding waves of incoming enemy's. There are many similarities between the two games, both involved avoiding zerging waves of enemies which created a high thrill "seat of your pants" gameplay. Gauntlet can be compared to many games including Diablo and other action RPG's though it is still very unique in its style. This was a genre defining game that has never been equalled and without doubt is a must play for all Action RPG fans. I give this remake a 9/10, it is very true to the original and that's what makes it great.WARNING: This is not a game for those who need Epic L00t as there is none. The gear you unlock by completing certain stages at different difficulty levels is purely cosmetic. Relics and Mastery levels add some abilities and increased power to your characters but these are the only none cosmetic customisations available.

content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												I bought this game as a 4 pack thinking my friends would enjoy it (4 of us total).   However, we all found the game more tedious and annoying than enjoyable.   The reward system in the game makes you want to gouge your eyes out with a dull spoon.   They tie the relics to potions which don't drop frequently enough to make them useful.  You end up "saving" the few you do get to the point where they become useless.   A better system would be that the potions boost the effectiveness of your relics.  The relics if not boosted, would be on some timer.  This would give you the thrill of feeling like you had some nice power to use in tight situations, but not make the game seem too easy.   Having potions to boost the effectiveness would give you the option to save the power until a very tough fight or simply clean house when you had the boost active.  The other annoying detail is the destructibility of the healing and relic powering potions.  The tight quarters force you to use your powerful aoe spells to survive.  However, those same spells blow up your only means of a) powering your relics and b) healing yourself.  I found myself driven into a frenzy of madness.  You are slivers away from death, surrounded, and forced to use your only means of defense to blow up enemies and unintentionally, your salvation.   We all gave up before we could finish it since the joy was sucked out of the game with annoying mechanics and a terrible loot / reward system.

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												A "Diablo lite".Manages to capture a portion of the feeling of the 1985 original. However, by today's standards the game doesn't offer much variety. Only a handful of useful items to purchase and not much in the way of character development. This does have the benefit of new players being able to jump right in to play with old players' characters, as a new character can be almost as useful as an old one. The flipside is that character development doesn't offer much incentive to keep playing.The campaign is a bit short, I'd estimate it will be over in 6-8 hours, but for 20 Eur it's an okay deal and the harder difficulty levels can extend its lifetime a bit.The real meat of the game is the co-op. The more friends you play with, the more fun you have, and although the game itself doesn't offer voice chat, using it is definitely recommended.At the time of the release the game seemed a bit unpolished and suffered from some cosmetic bugs (the end level mastery achievement descriptions seemed to have some wonky numbers) and some other small annoyances (enemies get rarely stuck inside obstacles making them difficult to kill, no text or voice chat etc.). Nothing gamebreaking though, and they'll hopefully be fixed in future updates.In conclusion, I wouldn't recommend this for single players, but groups of friends will have a blast. Don't shoot the food, man.

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 11, 2014
												I was reasonably interested to hear that a new Gauntlet game was in the pipeline BUT at that stage I didn't know which pipeline it was in. I hoped it wouldn't be coming from the same one which has blurted forth the gaming equivalent of hot, liquid turds in the name of Gauntlet since the 1980's.It seems that instead of serving us up complete effluent they have instead managed some kind of plumbing tomfoolery which has resulted in the effluent being mixed with cool, pure water. The resulting fluid can fill a glass but it is possibly not a glass one would choose to drink from. Some of the benefits of the game...1) Graphics are nice and (vaguely) evocative of the original game. Nothing looks bad and the game runs well. Everything looks reasonable for an arpg, tbh. Fairly stereotypical but then Gauntlet was pretty much first on the block for this kind of thing. However, there is little to no variation within a dungeon "set", which isn't in line with the original, there are just themed "worlds" which are not unlike the crap we had to munch through with "Gauntlet: Dark Legacy"2) Multiplayer works well, netcode seems tight. Now that the "cannot connect to Gauntlet online" random messages have ceased thanks to a post release patch, the netcode works well. Compared to something like Magicka which is still, imo, in a broken "online" state, Gauntlet runs perfectly. No real problems to report, no lag issues as such. 3) It's a good game for a little while, especially for fans of the original BUT this only lasts a short time. One of the key factors of the original was that there were a lot of different dungeons pooled randomly from a larger set, many of which could be flipped and changed in ways by the game before they were presented to the player. No two playthroughs would be quite the same. This is not the case in the new version, with only a few levels being occasionally "flipped" but they're very familiar whatever way round you do them after a very few playthroughs.BAD POINTS1) Skill trees have been added but instead of making the game something one would return to in order to "level up" items etc we are presented with something that's nothing more than a skin buying interface (buying skins with ingame money does nothing to your character and they are barely visible) and the option to buy "spells" (more on these on point 2). You can collect more than enough money very quickly to buy all of these things. Also, each upgrade is NOT character specific, with only 2 skills being particular to each character. This is nonsense. It just means, basically, that you're endlessly playing the game to unlock more of the same stuff (unlocks do not migrate across characters)2) Spells are terrible. "Potions" in the original Gauntlet worked as "Smart bombs" which would destroy onscreen monsters, particularly "Death" (More on this explained in point 3) but instead of keeping them the same the developers saw fit to wangle them into some rubbish kind of "Special move" enabling fandango. Preposterous. So, basically, you have to have a potion in your possession to perform your Special move. This means players simply signpost points in levels, grind out enough potions then all just launch the same kind of devastating, battle winning special. This renders the game really boring and, as a direct result of how the game progresses coupled with this stupid idea, the "end of level" bosses actually get progressively easier as the players become more invincible (in chosen situations). It's a really stupid, crappy system. They should have based these Special abilities on kills or a rage meter or something like that and kept potions the same. In the original game, the wizard could clear a screen by firing off a potion, with the other characters doing progressively less damage with them (warrior being least proficient). Potions were more rare, usually, whereas I feel the new version gives too many, with everyone able to just blast out specials by the time you reach the end of a particular dungeon set.3) Death is rubbish in this game. People who play/played Gauntlet will know what I mean but for the benefit of those not familiar, Death in Gauntlet is a physical character. In the original he would chase the players and steal health unless someone used a potion. Using a potion "killed" him, for the time being. There could be multiple "deaths" on one level, though. They were quite fun and an interesting alternative to ploughing through loads of "nasties". Anyway, "Death" is nothing like that in the new version. Instead of being in the main levels, he gets his own set of levels which really DO NOT WORK. They're not much fun and get old very quick. He appears, chases you for a bit, then disappears. This happens as you're pushed through a linear set of rooms and, yeah, gets old. Death is not remotely troublesome, either, and you can simply run round and round him. He even smashes crates/pots by passing over them so you can use him to collect money. He's basically rubbish in this version of the game, pushed into a sidequest of sorts (which is short and lame YET counts as a "main level")4) GENERATORS. GENERATORS, FOR CHRISTS SAKES, NOT "SUMMONING STONES". JESUS ! WTF !? The summoning stones are a BAD idea. They even sound rubbish. "GENERATOR" sounds so much more malevolent and directionless. "Summoning stones" take the place of generators in this version of the game but they're a really lame replacement. In the original, Generators were in place in the level anyway. You could see them from far away. In this version you will usually walk into a room, the doors will shut, and a Summoning Stone will appear. From this, enemies will come and you smash them up then smash the stone. Doors open. Proceed. Pretty lame, tbh. There are no "levels" of summoning stone, either, whereas the original game had varying strengths of Generator that spewed various strengths of creature. Also, there were ghost generators in the original game. In this game, ghosts are confined to just appearing on the "death" mini-levels. They just appear in tiny groups, following him. Useless. Gone are the days of masses of monsters (including ghosts, see LEVEL ONE IN THE ORIGINAL GAME FFS) generating and pushing at the backs of doors, instead we get the occasional room that's been "set up" with standing monsters but nothing like the original dungeons, creaking with scum to be destroyed. It's like everything in this game is just waiting for you to turn up before it'll appear, which takes away from the "world of absolute violence" vibe that many so loved about the original. Then again, that might just have been me. I'm asian.5) This is a SHORT game. It's not got anywhere near the replayability of the original and in a couple of playthroughs (or less) you'll most likely have enough gold to max everything on your (not very unique) character. It's really hurt by not having random levels of the kind offered by stuff like Full Mojo Rampage (and many other such games). With no real need (or, perhaps, desire ?) to replay for more xp and to enjoy some different levels, there's little to return to this game for and we, once again, encounter the same problem that has plagued all of the more modern Gauntlet updates. NOT ENOUGH GAME. Why, when the original paved the way for randomising such a large amount of gameplay elements do we have to put up with this NONSENSE ? We were even promised such things in this version of the game but there is no such thing (99% of the time) here. 6) Price. It's too expensive for what it is and the new character should have been free DLC. The base game doesn't contain a fair few things that were promised and just feels, well, way too short and shallow. It's good fun and the engine is sweet, the characters "play" well and all the new moves are fine but there need to be many more levels to make this worthwhile.6/10. I recommend Full Mojo Rampage instead.

number of helpful: 15 of 29 people (52%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
GauntletRating: 5 / 10(Played this game as a single player so this small review has been based upon that.)The Gauntlet is an action-rpg primarily focused on co-op party, but going in as a solo player is no problem. The game is a dungeon crawler so that's basically the only environment you encounter which becomes very boring after a while. As this is controller friendly, you loot and pick up items just by walking over them, and don't have to worry about an inventory because there isn't any. Upgrades of your equipment you buy at your local shop for the money you collect while grinding through the levels. There is no story at all, so you don't have to make choices or encounter npc's. The game focuses 100% on combat and when you're solo in the game this feels a bit lonely. The graphics aren't that great, the rendering distance is a bit too far. What I like is that you can dodge missiles and make use of your class specific skills. Crossing a dangerous floor is easier as a ranger than a warrior, just because you are quicker. Sound logical but in ARPG that isn't always the case.Fighting is clicking the right buttons. Warrior is the easiest, mage the most difficult as you have to remember button sequences which sounds a bit dated to me. Press this, than this and finally this to cast a spell. Very arcade yes, but hardly modern.As a solo player I can't recommend this because it is too boring and bland. There are lots of better action rpg's in the world to devote your time to. As a party game I can imagine it can be fun to play. For a while that is as the variety seems a little low.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Did you expect Diablo III or Torchlight II when you bought this game? If so, you're not going to have a very good time, as this game most certainly does not have the same level of character development and depth that either of those titles have.Did you expect this to be like FORCED, a co-operative puzzle game masquerading as a top-down ARPG? Again, you're going to be disappointed. While there is some degree of puzzle-solving (especially with the bosses), this is most definitely not the kind of game you're going to require sober friends for.What this is, is an honest, faithful reinvention of the original Gauntlet game for the arcade, peppered with modern features and graphics. The fun is striking that intricate balance between teamwork and sabotage, trying to hinder your competitors while helping them enough to finish the mission.Pros:- Combat is fluid and requires some degree of attention to finer detail. This isn't simply a button masher, and with the Wizard especially, a fair bit of concentration is required to come out of things with your skin intact.- Balance is strong; you never feel so overwhelmed that failure is the only option, but you're rarely bored either.- Along with Hammerwatch, it probably serves as the top choice for controller-supported 4-player couch co-op in the fantasy genre.- Fantastic game intro, giving you all you need to know about how to play the game in under 5 minutes.Cons:- Maximum supported resolution is 1600x900, and the fullscreen settings are finnicky, often reverting to windowed mode with a simple alt+tab.- Scenery is a bit drab and could use some variety and an expanded color palette.- Dungeons seem a bit too repetitive; random generation might need a revision or two later on.All in all, the game is well worth having in your library if you've got friends over enough to warrant it. There are definitely better solo options in the world than this.7.5/10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 18, 2015
												This 2014 edition of Gauntlet is a game I want to like, but that's simply impossible. It's a tedious, monotonous game with serious design problems. The game recently got polished into Gauntlet: Slayer Edition, but the problems remained.Conclusion: looks good, but not worth of any money. Maybe, if you get it for free, or as a part of humble bundle. Otherwise, no.Regrettably, this game is not fun to play at all.After 4 to 5 first levels the game starts to repeat itself. First levels are fairly enjoyable, but after that: nothing new. Controlling game characters (4 different + 1 dlc) is not rewarding, because most of the time your character is very hard to spot from the screen. That's because of three of the worst design flaws: walls obstruct your view, the viewpoint (camera) is zoomed out way too far away from your character AND the levels have very few light sources.Playing the game makes you wish you had binoculars and a flashlight pointed at the screen.How about multiplayer mode? You need a friend for that, because there is never anyone playing multiplayer otherwise. Once you get online with your friend, you will experience even more design flaws. You think you cannot get motion sickness from a game? I dare you to try this one on multiplayer mode. Have a bucket next to you when you try. I mean, what were the devs thinking? On single-player you have to strain your eyes to be able see your tiny character on a dim screen, and on multiplayer mode the screen jumps and jolts around making sure you'll vomit, or at least get a headache.Even if I pretend I can endure the flaws I mentioned, the boring map design and clearing a floor after a floor from the same enemies over and over again is just not worth the time. It is very sad to give this game thumbs down, because I really loved previous Gauntlet games, such as Gauntlet: Dark Legacy and the original Gauntlet and Gauntlet 2. Yes, even the original Gauntlet is less monotonous than this one. At least the original Gauntlet had proper level design and a feeling of progress in the game.

content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												Honestly this game dissapointed at every turn. As a long time fan of Gauntlet I have loved the action, unique world, humor and challenge of many gauntlet games but non of those appear in this rehash of a beloveld fanchise. All humor has been removed (which is ok, Gauntlet doesn't need to be funny) but it's replaced with dry attempt at what I can only guess is "wit" written to be understood by a 5 year old. The gameplay is stale, it's your typical button mash dungeon crawler with each class having a "unique" set of attacks. Unfortunately this leads to the final issue of difficulty, there is none. You will have no problems clearing mobs with simple repetition even on the hardest difficulties.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												I was extremely pleased to see that an this remake of a classic game did not create a sexpot Valkryie for fan service. She looks similar to the other characters in that she is scarred, she looks strong, and she obviously has some issues in her past.  I fully approve. Her frame is realistic to a warrior while still keping feminine traits, this is how it should be done.On actual game play; I have only played alone or with friends and I'm not sure this game would be fun with strangers online. It's really funny destroying the food when I'm alone but I can see that being frustrating as hell when trying to co-operate with others, for them and me.Game seems far, far too short. Hoping more levels will be added at later dates, hopefully for no rediculous fees but really... DLC quest really took the cake for satire humor that we're all pretty well used to. I'm sure there will be DLC in the future, I just hope they aren't too expensive and that they add extra characters and maybe skins as well as levels.Despite my complaints however, I do recommend this game.  It's difficult, it's challenging, it's funny, it's Gauntlet; even if it is a weak-sauce version of it.

content:

												Very fun game. It definitely smells of nostalgia. Graphics and sound are good and it definitely shows that the game is using the Magicka engine. Controls are fluid and responsive, however, I did find the pace of the game a bit slow. The mobs are massive and reminicent of the original.Multiplayer is a lot of fun and I don't think I'll ever play it on single player mode. Relics and items are ok, not really my thing, but hopefully, later on they'll add more items.This game has a lot of potential, but it hasn't reached it yet. I expect a ton of DLC to be released since there is a DLC folder in the game's installation.Big gripes right now is that I can't reconfigure the keys and I'm not sure how multiplayer will do in the future. As of now, since the game is new, it's pretty easy to hop on and find a game.Definitely recommend. I'd say this game is a 7.5 - 8 out of 10.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Did you expect Diablo III or Torchlight II when you bought this game? If so, you're not going to have a very good time, as this game most certainly does not have the same level of character development and depth that either of those titles have.Did you expect this to be like FORCED, a co-operative puzzle game masquerading as a top-down ARPG? Again, you're going to be disappointed. While there is some degree of puzzle-solving (especially with the bosses), this is most definitely not the kind of game you're going to require sober friends for.What this is, is an honest, faithful reinvention of the original Gauntlet game for the arcade, peppered with modern features and graphics. The fun is striking that intricate balance between teamwork and sabotage, trying to hinder your competitors while helping them enough to finish the mission.Pros:- Combat is fluid and requires some degree of attention to finer detail. This isn't simply a button masher, and with the Wizard especially, a fair bit of concentration is required to come out of things with your skin intact.- Balance is strong; you never feel so overwhelmed that failure is the only option, but you're rarely bored either.- Along with Hammerwatch, it probably serves as the top choice for controller-supported 4-player couch co-op in the fantasy genre.- Fantastic game intro, giving you all you need to know about how to play the game in under 5 minutes.Cons:- Maximum supported resolution is 1600x900, and the fullscreen settings are finnicky, often reverting to windowed mode with a simple alt+tab.- Scenery is a bit drab and could use some variety and an expanded color palette.- Dungeons seem a bit too repetitive; random generation might need a revision or two later on.All in all, the game is well worth having in your library if you've got friends over enough to warrant it. There are definitely better solo options in the world than this.7.5/10

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												Gauntlet is back, kind of!  Some wizard wants to build a sword or something, but it's in pieces and scattered through The Gauntlet, and it's up to you to find them.  You have four* intrepid adventurers to choose from, with varying stats, moves, and strengths, but all sharing one major weakness.  The controls in this game are awful.  Movement is simple, but from your top-down view, you better see and plan all your moves way in advance, because characters will commit to sword swings, queue up commands, not actually get the invincibility frames the in-game help claims some moves have, and otherwise get you killed, a lot.  A hack-n-slash simply demands more responsive, maybe even twitchy controls, especially when every single room surrounds you with enemies.  If you want to play Dark Souls zoomed way out and surrounded by enemies, try Gauntlet.  If you want a game that has the frenetic, responsive, coherent feel of old-school Gauntlet...this game doesn't have that.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												I have fond memories of the original Gauntlet. I remember playing the Amstrad CPC version for a whole day, only taking breaks for food. I also had the Gauntlet Legacy games which I thought were ok but too different from the original game. This latest incarnation of Gauntlet does not disappoint. It retains aspects of the original: 4p co-op, overwhelming numbers of enemies and a good dose of humour. It's a great homage to the original with many elements that have been updated to modern standards.This game surpasses the original in my opinion which is no mean feat. Each character plays very differently. My favourite is the wizard who is tricky to use at first but when mastered can be very powerful.I've seen some reviews which accuse the game of being repetitive. There is some truth in that, especially when you have to restart a level from the beginning. The action is so fun that I don't mind repeating the same level again and it also allows you to gain more gold and level up your character.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												Arrowhead has adopted the franchise from Midway Games and has decided to reboot it. Not re-iterate the story, not make a sequel, but to reboot it. In order to do so, they decided to go back to the original arcade games from the 1980's and take a few pointer tips for their inspiration of level design.However, instead of endless dungeons that the originals produced, this game focuses on more of a linear storyline.Three worlds - One Boss per worldFour levels each -Three stages per level (Explore, Race, Challenge Arena)Four difficulties - Easy, Normal, Hard, UnfairFour characters to select, five with DLC - Warrior, Knight, Wizard, Elf, & Necromancer*Online and Local Co-op with up to three other players!Different Masteries per character to unlockGone are the days of treasure chests and a variety of potions to unleash upon the hordes.Nowadays we are prone to smashing pots and boxes for gold. You do collect a potion throughout the entire game, you use these to display your special ability in combat. Special abilties can be bought at the in-game store and you can have up to two at once.Different skins for your weapon and character are buyable as well, but they are just for looks.Many complain this game is bland, but it is really just inspired by the "bland-ness" of 1980's retro arcade games. The look and feel is all intentional. If you enjoy that nostalgia, then the price is worth it.It is a retro rpg - hack and slash - dungeon crawler. You either love it or you shame it. 8/10

												This game is awful. I enjoyed Gauntlet Legends on the old consoles - this is nothing like it. There are only 4 characters (+1 if you buy a ridiculously expensive addon), and they don't learn any new abilities ever. Equipment is all cosmetic, so there are practically no upgrades except for a small "perk" system which you won't feel unless you log a lot of playtime. The levels are boring and flat with few puzzles that the old games had, and the bosses are totally uninteresting. There is not even the token storyline that the old game had, and the basic characters they did add in are ugly. I don't know what kind of nostalgia feeling other people are getting from this, but I had no enjoyment at all.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2015
												"Stay a while and listen" (blizzy pls don't sue me, k, thx, bai!) ... or in this case, read a wall of text  :PWhat I first noticed about the game is its menu, it's simple, clear, all a menu should be.Then the game started with the tutorial, forcing me to play it. I did not see a "skip tutorial" button (my bad if there was but pretty sure there wasn't).Not nice forcing people to do something they don't want to, give them the option to choose.And if you are going to argue that they had to do that the way they did so people would learn about the characters and their mechanics then i say to you: "I'm sorry but I do not agree!"There are better ways to introduce important stuff then forcing it on people, hide it like Portal and Portal 2 did - almost the whole game is a tutorial preparing the player for what is to come, but we are not here to talk about Portal, Gauntlet time.The tutorial on its own was put together nicely, introducing the characters and their mechanics through gameplay rather then through text, which is always nice.The characters are ok-ish defined.The Warrior being a warrior can take damage as well as dish out damage of his own.The Elf uses range attacks to defeat his enemies, although his range isn't that great. I expected more from an elf ranger.The Valkyrie is a nice mix of the two (i particularly liked the Captain America like shield throw).These three characters are pretty straightforward, but the Wizard is a bit more complicated.Having 9 spells to choose from, the Wizard can access his spells with a certain button combination. The desired spell is then ready to use, assuming its not on cooldown.Not too intuitive, and a bit confusing at first but fiddle around with the spell combinations and you will get the hang of it.I must point out that the ice spells were not as useful to me as the other two types of spells (fire and lightning) and i ended up playing mostly with fire and lightning spells, and even here with not all of them.The Fire Bomb is useless if you are near a doorway or a low ceiling-ish area it will hit the ceiling and explode dealing no damage to the monsters below it or it won't end up exploding where you expected it to cause it ended up hitting something you did not thought possible (could be a bug or just bad design).Also Lightning Discharge was of no use to me, if i wanted to knock someone back I can use my Storm Barrier, so I ended up using it only when I incorrectly combined buttons to get a spell.The RPG elements are kind of wierd in concept and implementation.If you buy armour and weapons you only get a cosmetic change. But you can also buy relics to give you buffs to your speed, damage, attack speed or the ability to summon illusions or a demonic gargoyle to fight by your side.However you can only have 2 relics and can not use any without potions. These potions you can not buy, they can only be found throughout the levels, as well as food which restores hit points.Instead of gaining traditional levels for each character, you can only improve your stats by performing achievement-like actions called Masteries. For example killing 10,000 monsters grants a 10 % damage bonus.First time around, the structure of the game is interesting and the level design is a mix of pre-made and randomly generated environment.Some levels are more complex than others, tasking you or the group to push blocks, insert statues into spots, or fill a lava pool to raise a bridge and then finally an okay-ish boss battle.The campaign is broken up into three acts, with four stages, four repetitive stages.Each set of those stages unfolds in the same way:First you start with a standard level, then you move on to a shorter level with a frustrating twist like being chased by death which btw is bad at its job and its not so hard to outrun (just frustrating) or a dark cave eating away at your nerves as you try to hold back the urge to pluck out your hair and then (as i already mentioned) a boss fight.Higher difficulty only makes enemies more resistant to damage and drop more gold.Once the campaign is finished there’s not much incentive to revisit and replay the game.The A.I. is not to bright either. Getting stuck frequently on each other, corners, doorways and other stuff lying around the level.After some time you notice how they move and can kite them around the level making them easy targets. Easier than they would have been on their own.And a one last thing, the camera, oh boy ... The view is zoomed out far enough to cover an area, but not far enough for a four player co-op play through. The camera does not follow any player controlled characters but hovers above an area of the level and its easy to lose sight of your character.Additionally if any teammate goes idle you can't move on without them cause the camera will stand still in an area and try to cover all players.I am sure that Arrowhead did their best but they neither went full retro nor did they break from the past.As i see this game, its like they tried to stay close to the original (Gauntlet from 1985) but not to close cause people my not like it today and tried to make it an appealing 2014 role-play, dungeon crawl, hack and slash game but actually got stuck in the middle of it all resulting in a not so good game.In short its repetitive and overly simplistic, awkward camera, an uninteresting upgrade system and too little substance or variety to satisfy players.However, with four committed players the co-op works well, and it’s certainly not the worst Gauntlet revamp there’s ever been.All in all IMHO this game is a 5.5 / 10, nice try but u failed, sry and i do not recommend this game.

If anyone has any tips to get it to work it would be appreciated and I wouldn't mind changing the review to positive. But for now it seems like that's $10 down the drain.

content:
Posted: October 4, 2014
												I love Gauntlet!  The series, the feel of the game, and all that the Gauntlet series has offered up to this point.  However, I'm a bit dissapointed with Gauntlet for the PC.  Briefly put, this game falls short of my expectations.  I expected to see more levels, abilitys, and monsters.  To start, the feel of the original Gauntlet is missing.  I jumped into the first few levels, and didn't feel absorbed into the Gauntlet world, and the feel of the levels fall a bit short as well.  The game boasts 12 levels and in the end it just doesn't feel like enough.  An endless mode, or additional levels would be nice to see in the game.The game isn't horrible, but it's not what I like in Gauntlet games.  I expect to jump into a game and play with 4 people and feel like I'm playing Gauntlet.  I feel that this game may meet that potential after a few updates.  I will still be playing the game, but it does not meet these expectations.  I hope that some changes are made.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												Arrowhead has adopted the franchise from Midway Games and has decided to reboot it. Not re-iterate the story, not make a sequel, but to reboot it. In order to do so, they decided to go back to the original arcade games from the 1980's and take a few pointer tips for their inspiration of level design.However, instead of endless dungeons that the originals produced, this game focuses on more of a linear storyline.Three worlds - One Boss per worldFour levels each -Three stages per level (Explore, Race, Challenge Arena)Four difficulties - Easy, Normal, Hard, UnfairFour characters to select, five with DLC - Warrior, Knight, Wizard, Elf, & Necromancer*Online and Local Co-op with up to three other players!Different Masteries per character to unlockGone are the days of treasure chests and a variety of potions to unleash upon the hordes.Nowadays we are prone to smashing pots and boxes for gold. You do collect a potion throughout the entire game, you use these to display your special ability in combat. Special abilties can be bought at the in-game store and you can have up to two at once.Different skins for your weapon and character are buyable as well, but they are just for looks.Many complain this game is bland, but it is really just inspired by the "bland-ness" of 1980's retro arcade games. The look and feel is all intentional. If you enjoy that nostalgia, then the price is worth it.It is a retro rpg - hack and slash - dungeon crawler. You either love it or you shame it. 8/10

content:
Posted: June 6, 2015
												*scaled rating at the end. This review is based on single player experience.*Thumbs up because I like the franchise.  BUT....This is not the gauntlet that you know and love.  It reminds me more of Bastion but Bastion is much better.  This a rogue-like game but with NO RPG elements.  Your character does not get better at all.  But the monsters get tougher and more plentiful.The achievement masteries, I guess, are supposed to be the RPG elements.  But adding 1% damage does nothing as an achievement payoff.  That's like giving a whale a tic-tac.  The potions are almost useless.  Some sections you get very few so you cant use the relics you buy.Believe the other reviews that say it short.  VERY short.  And the replay value is absolutely boring.  The developers expect  you to play each character (5 with the DLC) on each difficulty level (4).  To be a completist and unlock all the masteries, this is what you have to do.  And playing the wizard is a grindfest.I bought this day one because I love the Gauntlet franchise.  I pumped many quarters in the original arcade machine and played all the nintendo games.  It's fun but this is not Guantlet.  DONOT spend full price.  Wait for an 80% off sale.Graphics 9/10Audio 9/10Controls/UI 9/10Immersion 7/10Grind Level 8/10Replay Value 2/10Overall fun 5/10

content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
												The game is mediocre at best.  I never played any of the previous Gauntlets so I never felt any nostalgia people wrote in their reviews.  I felt the game had a lot of potential but it fell flat.  The graphics were decent and made the game looked very interesting in the screenshots.  However, the game was extremely repetitive.  You literally grind variations of the same 3 path dungeon 3 times (so you play each path 3 times) then you reach boss.  There is absolutely no replay value.I played D3 when it first launched and I thought it was fast.  Well, this game is even faster.  However, there is incentive to grind in D3 for better gear.  Here, you grind to level up your skill but really you just get a longer duration or deal more damage with your skill most of the time.A lot of people said this is a coop game and I imagine this might be the reason.  I played single player and felt the game was really boring the whole time.  The only real replay incentive is if you want to beat at the highest level of difficulty (there are easy, normal, hard and unfair).  I bought this with a discount so it didn't hurt me as much but I rather have spent it on another game now that I know this one is bad.  I really hated the voice acting for the elf.  The voice acting fits a thief character where he sounds a bit sly.  I honestly imagine the best class would be wizard with complex skills... but I really am not interested enough to want to find out.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												Gauntlet is a series of games consist of hack n' slash dungeon crawlers.  The games have been pretty straightforward and enjoyable, and this version of Gauntlet doesn't deviate too far from the formula.  Gauntlet isn't an HD remake of the first game.  It is a modernized retelling, keeping some things but adding in a few new things to change things up---with mixed results.Gauntlet is a decent looking game that plays pretty well.  The game's strongest point is how each character plays.  The four choices (Warrior, Valkyrie, Wizard, and Elf) have relatively unique playstyles.  You'll have to excuse my controller references coming up, but the Warrior and Valkyrie can be most closely associated with "button mashers," relying more on the face buttons to perform commands.  The Wizard and Elf, on the other hand, are "twin-stick" shooters, relying on heavy use of the right analog stick.  Each character also has special abilities to offer further variety, but the most diverse character is the Wizard.  While the other characters are easily accessible, the Wizard has a learning curve due to the number of abilities he has (in comparison to the others).The game still stays true to its hack n' slash, dungeon crawling roots.  The game tries to have some kind of story for why the characters are thrust into the Gauntlet, but it is paper-thin---almost unnecessary.  I know we're supposed to be collecting shards for a sword, but I really just wanted to kill some monsters with my friends.  Now, something that makes this game stand apart from other dungeon crawlers is the lack of a leveling system.  Your character doesn't gain levels (they do gain "masteries," but more on this shortly), and is just about fully equiped with every ability they will ever have.  I find this to be a welcome break, and it helps keep the game accessible to anyone.Unfortunately, I found there to be more negatives than positives to this game.  The game offers up "masteries," which are basically perks that require a lot of investment.  Most of the revolve around killing enemies, but having to continuously play through levels to kill enemies is rather annoying.  If, perhaps, the mastery requirements were lower or if they were shared across all characters (where applicable), I wouldn't be as annoyed with the mechanic.  However, the amount of work and time needed to entirely unlock them isn't worth it, in most cases.  The rewards are so incremental that it makes me wonder why they're there.Something that may also help is a stronger level variety.  There are 30 levels in the game.  27 of them are part of 9 "standard" levels and the other 3 are boss levels.  When selecting a non-boss level, you are committed to a three-level endurance run that, despite the aesthetic changes, all follow the same formula: 1st level is a "long, standard" level, 2nd level is a "short, environment hazard" level, and 3rd level is an "arena" fight.  Given that the levels are not procedurally generated (a "hot" item in more recent dungeon crawlers), the replayability falls short.  The bosses aren't incredibly fun to fight either, making them rather underwhelming.Another downfall about the level structure is the "hub" area.  After completing either the series of 3 levels or a boss level, all players are transported to the hub area to select a new level or purchase items.  The game offers the players items in the form of relics---which can only be used if potions are collected, or loadouts---which are only cosmetic permutations for the characters.  The relics offer a little more variety to the potions (instead of just "clear the screen of enemies") and the permutations don't hurt the game at all, but relics can never be used on bosses and the loadouts require us to beat the bosses and specific difficulties to unlock (and even then they cost gold to purchase).  This game also harkens back to the original Gauntlet by restricting the group to one unique character per player.  We cannot all play as Wizards or Warriors in a 4-player group.  I like the idea of having team variety, but forcing it typically leads to a lot of players quitting from a game since they can't play as a character they've invested time into.  However, as with most games, playing this game with more people is always a good time, and with a recent patch text chat has been made available.  On top of the other tweaks that have happened since the game's launch in September, it is apparent that the developer's aren't just letting this game settle.  They plan to keep improving it.SummaryPros:Graphics aren't terrible; very likely this game will run on anything.Controller supportEach character has a unique playstyleCo-op is fun; online and LAN.Developers still working out the kinks and making updates.Cons:Game is a bit on the short side.Not enough levels, and not enough level variety to keep things interesting.Can't have multiple people playing as the same character.Game wants you to grind, but not get the benefit of gaining levels.Relics and loadouts don't really offer much to the game.Poor, and at times laughable voice acting.Suggestions:Start using procedural level design.  While it isn't a perfect fix, having a structured level design when having to replay levels makes the experience too linear and predictable.Get crazier with the boss and level designs.  Maybe have something that requires more teamwork, or include some more variety with the environmental hazards.  Adding puzzles would definitely be a plus.Add an endurance mode.  All levels must be played in succession; no hub area breaks.  Even better: 100 levels, like the original game.Allow mutliple people to play as the same character.  The group may not be as varied this way, but I'd rather have another player in the group than have them drop out due to their character being taken already.Drop the relics, or make potions transfer from area to area.  Not having relics for boss fights is a poor design choice.Drop the loadouts for character creation.  Sure, the characters we play as are fully-voiced characters with small stories.  I'd rather see them not truly be characters but rather avatars for ourselves.  We can customize them, and unlocking these permutations actually unlocks them---no grinding for gold to buy them after unlocking them.Drop the masteries, or have them be cumulative across all characters when applicable.  Getting 50,000 kills for one character for a 25% damage output increase is a tall order.  Asking for that for all four characters is ridiculous.  Having shared masteries would also make the transition from playing as one character to another a bit easier on the player.Despite my lists of complaints, I am still recommending the game.  I do not think this game has earned my $20 just yet, but perhaps with additional updates down the road it will get even better.  Right now, I'd say the game is worth a $10 purchase.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2015
												Challenges can be fun. And Gauntlet has the fundamentals of a great challenge: interesting tools for split-second decision making, and difficult encounters that demand you play your very best.Unfortunately, there are some awful design decisions and sloppy glitches that spoil what would otherwise have been a classic action game.First, the pacing: Gauntlet has historically been a very fast-paced game. But the obstacles in this Gauntlet are often extremely tedious. Monster spawners take ages to destroy, and you'll have to do it over and over again. Once you've found the right strategy, you'll just be repeating that approach every time, while hoping that one of the game's many glitches doesn't ruin your attempt.Among these bugs: Enemies will get stuck, invincibly, inside walls; the player character will get stuck in the world; collision detection screws up frequently; attacks will miss enemies directly in front of you; small elevation changes will render abilities useless (God help you if you try to fight on stairs); your defensive skills will sometimes fail to work; and relics can cause your character to lock up.Any of these glitches can lead to a cheap death, and that often means losing 20+ minutes worth of progress, since the game's rewards are gated behind challenges like "complete three levels in a row on the hardest difficulty without dying once," while your character dies in a split second if you screw up, or the game does.While Gauntlet seems suited for a quick jump-in, jump-out pace, the level structure actually requires completing several very lengthy levels in a row, which gets very tiring, especially when they consist of the same obstacles over and over. The level design itself is poor, with lots of boring, winding paths, thoughtless blob-shaped rooms, and cheap traps. In one of the randomly-selected sections, there's a room that can trap your character by requiring a key to exit yet not including a key anywhere in the room, or any way to backtrack, forcing a restart.There are fun elements here, but it's a sloppy product.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
												I have fond memories of the original Gauntlet. I remember playing the Amstrad CPC version for a whole day, only taking breaks for food. I also had the Gauntlet Legacy games which I thought were ok but too different from the original game. This latest incarnation of Gauntlet does not disappoint. It retains aspects of the original: 4p co-op, overwhelming numbers of enemies and a good dose of humour. It's a great homage to the original with many elements that have been updated to modern standards.This game surpasses the original in my opinion which is no mean feat. Each character plays very differently. My favourite is the wizard who is tricky to use at first but when mastered can be very powerful.I've seen some reviews which accuse the game of being repetitive. There is some truth in that, especially when you have to restart a level from the beginning. The action is so fun that I don't mind repeating the same level again and it also allows you to gain more gold and level up your character.

												I shot an elite silver platter of roasted turkey and got insulted by a wizard. 10/10This is a great game, while not spectacular on the graphics, it is extremely challenging and does require a lot of team work. Everyone seems to have expected this to be some easy hack'n'slash game but it really takes more talent then smashing B button while charging like rambo into mobs. With a great team, it's easily one of the most fun Co-ops I've played in awhile. I wish more games like this would get out there and expand a lot more.My only complain is it has a lack of levels, it boasted how they would be random every time but I really don't see a difference when I play, they all look the exact same to me. Total you get about 12 maps to play on and 4 difficulties, which even as sad as that amount of content is, it's still a lot of fun to play with friends.However, I will say that joining random teams is a real pain. Everyone wants to be archer or wizard and refuses to even try the melee class. Many players scream about how terrible they are, and I do think it is a little unfair that the wizard gets 9 spells and everyone else only has 3 skills, BUT they are not weak and, while playing the wizard, I have seen the Valk/Thor kill so much so fast I couldnt even get kills. I actually have a friend that is a beast at playing the valk and have seen Thor♥♥♥♥♥♥the entire map by himself on a 4-player.I definitely say it's worth buying for some co-op fun, but I do hope to see some serious content expansion in the future. I'd sugggest buying it from {LINK REMOVED} since 20$ is a high price for it in its current state. I bought it for about 13$.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 5, 2014
												This is modern Gauntlet. You could call it a remake, but it's not really that. It's so much better. It's a dungeon crawler and arena twin-stick shooter. It's Gauntlet on steroids, but it hasn't lost that old-school charm. Best played with others, especially when you get into Hard and above.The biggest flaws I've seen are a lack of variation on encounters. This was a chance for the team to take Gauntlet even farther, but they stuck with something more tried and true. Granted, it's been refined so that the annoyances of a generation ago aren't still here. There's also a new relic system to give you some sense of progression other than making it through the dungeon. But at it's core, it's the same sets of encounters over and over again, and when you've seen them once, you've seen them.My other big gripe is that the loadouts do nothing but change how your character is dressed. Certainly they could have given some other bonus, especially with some of them requiring you beat certain levels on specific difficulties. At the very least, they could have made the loadouts be more visually interesting, because right now, they're a bit boring. I'm not really interested in spending my hard-earned gold on them for such little gain.That doesn't make the game not great though. The normal campaign will last you about 6-8 hours depending on your abilities and that's not bad. Add in additional difficulty levels and you've got a competent remake. The added charm of the announcer quipping about Warrior needing food, badly, or the food being shot by the clever wizard harken back to the game we all know and love.The story is a bit drab and predictable, but you're not here for the story, so who gives a♥♥♥♥♥♥ The visuals are great, the sound and music fit the game perfectly, and the difficulty scales well. All-in-all, the Arrowhead team has done a great job! I look forward to Gauntlet 2.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
												Gauntlet is a series of games consist of hack n' slash dungeon crawlers.  The games have been pretty straightforward and enjoyable, and this version of Gauntlet doesn't deviate too far from the formula.  Gauntlet isn't an HD remake of the first game.  It is a modernized retelling, keeping some things but adding in a few new things to change things up---with mixed results.Gauntlet is a decent looking game that plays pretty well.  The game's strongest point is how each character plays.  The four choices (Warrior, Valkyrie, Wizard, and Elf) have relatively unique playstyles.  You'll have to excuse my controller references coming up, but the Warrior and Valkyrie can be most closely associated with "button mashers," relying more on the face buttons to perform commands.  The Wizard and Elf, on the other hand, are "twin-stick" shooters, relying on heavy use of the right analog stick.  Each character also has special abilities to offer further variety, but the most diverse character is the Wizard.  While the other characters are easily accessible, the Wizard has a learning curve due to the number of abilities he has (in comparison to the others).The game still stays true to its hack n' slash, dungeon crawling roots.  The game tries to have some kind of story for why the characters are thrust into the Gauntlet, but it is paper-thin---almost unnecessary.  I know we're supposed to be collecting shards for a sword, but I really just wanted to kill some monsters with my friends.  Now, something that makes this game stand apart from other dungeon crawlers is the lack of a leveling system.  Your character doesn't gain levels (they do gain "masteries," but more on this shortly), and is just about fully equiped with every ability they will ever have.  I find this to be a welcome break, and it helps keep the game accessible to anyone.Unfortunately, I found there to be more negatives than positives to this game.  The game offers up "masteries," which are basically perks that require a lot of investment.  Most of the revolve around killing enemies, but having to continuously play through levels to kill enemies is rather annoying.  If, perhaps, the mastery requirements were lower or if they were shared across all characters (where applicable), I wouldn't be as annoyed with the mechanic.  However, the amount of work and time needed to entirely unlock them isn't worth it, in most cases.  The rewards are so incremental that it makes me wonder why they're there.Something that may also help is a stronger level variety.  There are 30 levels in the game.  27 of them are part of 9 "standard" levels and the other 3 are boss levels.  When selecting a non-boss level, you are committed to a three-level endurance run that, despite the aesthetic changes, all follow the same formula: 1st level is a "long, standard" level, 2nd level is a "short, environment hazard" level, and 3rd level is an "arena" fight.  Given that the levels are not procedurally generated (a "hot" item in more recent dungeon crawlers), the replayability falls short.  The bosses aren't incredibly fun to fight either, making them rather underwhelming.Another downfall about the level structure is the "hub" area.  After completing either the series of 3 levels or a boss level, all players are transported to the hub area to select a new level or purchase items.  The game offers the players items in the form of relics---which can only be used if potions are collected, or loadouts---which are only cosmetic permutations for the characters.  The relics offer a little more variety to the potions (instead of just "clear the screen of enemies") and the permutations don't hurt the game at all, but relics can never be used on bosses and the loadouts require us to beat the bosses and specific difficulties to unlock (and even then they cost gold to purchase).  This game also harkens back to the original Gauntlet by restricting the group to one unique character per player.  We cannot all play as Wizards or Warriors in a 4-player group.  I like the idea of having team variety, but forcing it typically leads to a lot of players quitting from a game since they can't play as a character they've invested time into.  However, as with most games, playing this game with more people is always a good time, and with a recent patch text chat has been made available.  On top of the other tweaks that have happened since the game's launch in September, it is apparent that the developer's aren't just letting this game settle.  They plan to keep improving it.SummaryPros:Graphics aren't terrible; very likely this game will run on anything.Controller supportEach character has a unique playstyleCo-op is fun; online and LAN.Developers still working out the kinks and making updates.Cons:Game is a bit on the short side.Not enough levels, and not enough level variety to keep things interesting.Can't have multiple people playing as the same character.Game wants you to grind, but not get the benefit of gaining levels.Relics and loadouts don't really offer much to the game.Poor, and at times laughable voice acting.Suggestions:Start using procedural level design.  While it isn't a perfect fix, having a structured level design when having to replay levels makes the experience too linear and predictable.Get crazier with the boss and level designs.  Maybe have something that requires more teamwork, or include some more variety with the environmental hazards.  Adding puzzles would definitely be a plus.Add an endurance mode.  All levels must be played in succession; no hub area breaks.  Even better: 100 levels, like the original game.Allow mutliple people to play as the same character.  The group may not be as varied this way, but I'd rather have another player in the group than have them drop out due to their character being taken already.Drop the relics, or make potions transfer from area to area.  Not having relics for boss fights is a poor design choice.Drop the loadouts for character creation.  Sure, the characters we play as are fully-voiced characters with small stories.  I'd rather see them not truly be characters but rather avatars for ourselves.  We can customize them, and unlocking these permutations actually unlocks them---no grinding for gold to buy them after unlocking them.Drop the masteries, or have them be cumulative across all characters when applicable.  Getting 50,000 kills for one character for a 25% damage output increase is a tall order.  Asking for that for all four characters is ridiculous.  Having shared masteries would also make the transition from playing as one character to another a bit easier on the player.Despite my lists of complaints, I am still recommending the game.  I do not think this game has earned my $20 just yet, but perhaps with additional updates down the road it will get even better.  Right now, I'd say the game is worth a $10 purchase.

content:
Posted: October 6, 2014
												I have very mixed reviews about this game. First off, I have heard a lot of the Gauntlet series and the only one I've ever played was Dark Legacy on Gamecube. It had crappy graphics, lame gameplay, nothing complicated but it had something that this Gauntlet did not have..The charm to make me laugh.Gauntlet, a dungeon crawler I have not played for a long time is a fairly decent game. Comparing it with Diablo would be unfair, since Diablo was a very unbalanced game. Gauntlet is a very well balanced game with no over-powered character and completely very different play styles between the 4 classes with Wizard being the most complicated but most rewardingly exciting character to wield. Good graphics and pretty much zero story is normal for a game like this. It is straight-forward and simple to get used to.But Gauntlet's greatest strength for balanced gameplay and better graphics is its very own downfall. It kept the basic skeleton of what Gauntlet is, but it lacked the charm and uniqueness to stand apart from any other dungeon crawler game, let alone apart from Dark Legacy. It was straightforward, but that's all it is, straightforward with a spice of linear and a topping of repetitionWhat made Dark Legacy truly great is how wacky it was with stupid skills, range attacks for all classes and melee when your character was dealing face-to-face against an enemy. Of course, some excel in one thing while others excel in theirs. Death was also wacky as heck, chasing us like mad while leeching our lives. It had a load of flaws...but those flaws (like Halo1) was it's biggest asset and uniqueness that made me and my friends laugh through the night.This Gauntlet has stripped away all that charm and replaced it with standard issued factory produced games that can be found anywhere at their bare skeleton. Sure the game requires some skill to play, esspecially with the wizard, but it's not enough to compensate for the lack of fun factor. It's a serious dungeon crawler...and very little levels and character classes. Leveling should have been the better option to keep me playing since there are so few classes. But if there were a ton more kinds of classes, it's current balanced style would have complimented it. Much to experience and much to experiment.With so little dungeons, unworthy winnings barely worth gaining, very little items to buy...Gauntlet is a decent game, and that's all it is. Decent. I haven't even laughed once since I started playing this game online. It truly made me believe that Dark Legacy was truly better than this Gauntlet.5 out of 10 is all I can give it. It's a little fun and has it's moments of intensity which I enjoyed. But I'm not laughing and going gaga over this game. I'm already bored of it.The developers should have taken risks, and did something stupid yet playable rather than trying so hard to make this game perfect and flawless. It's flaws and improvements are both professionally unfun to endure compared to Dark Legacy. It's genericly fun for few hours. That's the most you'd get out of it.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 4, 2015
												An interesting but weak reboot. Some design decisions are nonsensical. Networking is atrocious, which makes online play a moot point. Upgrading is slow and takes a long time for no good reasons, and upgrades are incredibly minor in most cases. The characters are annoying yet somehow unintentionally funny in how cliche they are. It reminds me strongly of a game that was made way back in the day to spoof Gauntlet, known as Get Medieval. Strangely, each character class does not control best with the same control scheme. Using mokey for the elf is a serious advantage, while using anything but a controller for the other classes is a mistake. The wizard is not playable with mokey, so don't even.Bizarrely when playing online each player must choose a different class. They fixed that♥♥♥♥♥♥when Gauntlet 2 hit the arcades back in the day, there's no excuse for this complete retardation.Worth it on sale maybe, but not otherwise. If you own Diablo 3 you will never have a reason to play this game. Slightly recommended.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 28, 2014
												I really liked the old Gauntlet. This one requires teamwork and a lot of trial and error. You will die, very easily.The classes are varied and fun to play with. My favorite is the Elf. It runs really well with never a dip in frames or stutters when the mobs fill the screen.There isn't too much replay value. You do unlock different powers and cosmetic gear but thats about it. Playing with friends wether online, local or even both is where the meat of the game is. As of this writing I had no problem finding people to p[lay with. It's fun and worth the $20 price. Just don't expect the depth of Hammerwatch or Torchlight.If you like dungeon crawlers and co-op games this is a goodie. 8/10

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Awesome if you like the style of gameplay from the original Gauntlet. If you like the preview videos of the gameplay, chances are you'll like the game. There is one annoying thing, though. Playing Merlin online. You compete for gold with the other players, and he has, by far, the longest cooldown on his dash ability. This means you're pretty much always getting the least gold. He also has more utility, but he has to use a lot more skills to be on equal ground to other characters. If you like challenges he'll be a great character. Seems to have a few OP abilities, but the cooldown on them is long enough to make him boring for me. But if you don't mind slightly longer cooldowns but a lot more options, maybe he'll be good for you. Just be sure to save that dash for getting gold, if possible (half the time it's not possible). Players are brutal on this game when it comes to gold, but it's all in good fun.10/10

content:
Posted: July 28, 2015
												Are you wishing to find something similar to good old Diablo 2, but with the ability to move with the WASD-keys, aim with the mouse and more or less wave-zombie-survival-like gameplay? Look no further.Gauntlet is a great game for both playing solo or in a party. Choose one of five classic characters: Barbarian (aka The Warrior)Valkyre (aka The Tank)Archer (-_-)Wizard (aka Invoker's little bro)or Necromancer (aka The DLC-chick)and get into the fight through the vast dungeons full of monsters, traps, TURKEY and GOLD! The more you play and the more you kill - the more powerful you get, opening new bonuses and abilities.Sharpen your axe and spear, stretch your bow or ....? your spellbook and dive into action!

content:
Posted: February 20, 2015
												The game is immersive with graphics that, although not cutting edge, seem right for the overall plot. Control system for the keyboard will take a little getting used to as movement is by seperate keybindings and targeting is by curser. Charcters begin with sufficient skills to enable advancement, and despite the possibly overcomplicated wizard spell system, all playable. Necro is however possibly the best character to use - just ensure you have space to use abilities. Multiplayer is recommended.

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 30, 2014
												While its not going to revolutionize the Gauntlet name or make it onto anyone's Top 10 games of 2014, Gauntlet is still a fun romp that gets better with friends, and is an excellent restart for the franchise. The gameplay is largely mindless, not many decisions need to be made even if you're playing as the most complex class, but feels rewarding and enjoyable if you can stomach the grindy nature of it. Harder difficulties are recommended, turning the game into a zombie/demon/orc melee extravaganza that requires a good amount of skill or luck to get through unscathed. Story is almost non-existant, but the characters are amusing and good for a few laughs, especially if paired together in co-op where they will play off each other. Playable solo, but much more grindy in nature this way. This is the type of game to play on a friday night with some friends and some beers, it doesn't take too much effort but can still be challenging and leads to some fun stories.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Awesome if you like the style of gameplay from the original Gauntlet. If you like the preview videos of the gameplay, chances are you'll like the game. There is one annoying thing, though. Playing Merlin online. You compete for gold with the other players, and he has, by far, the longest cooldown on his dash ability. This means you're pretty much always getting the least gold. He also has more utility, but he has to use a lot more skills to be on equal ground to other characters. If you like challenges he'll be a great character. Seems to have a few OP abilities, but the cooldown on them is long enough to make him boring for me. But if you don't mind slightly longer cooldowns but a lot more options, maybe he'll be good for you. Just be sure to save that dash for getting gold, if possible (half the time it's not possible). Players are brutal on this game when it comes to gold, but it's all in good fun.10/10

content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												Gauntlet may seem like the standard dungeon crawler at first but the gameplay is nothing short of glorious. As you tear through swarms of goons like a kid and christmas presents, the first glimpse you catch is the Warrior spinning his axe. Then you spot the Elf rapid-firing shots from a distance. Amidst the chaos you notice the Wizard blasting off spells and the Valkyie handing out slayings. What makes the game special is that four player unity. Together the players bring out the best of what a modern co-op game should, and in harmonious fashion. The evidence is in the legacy. The game isn't perfect. Then again the best things never are.Note: This is for Pre-Slayer Edition. RIP.
