number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
												I didn't play the original Gauntlet or any of its follow-ups, so this is coming from a fresh perspective, and I won't be drawing any comparisons between this game and earlier iterations of Gauntlet.This game is simple, but robust; four characters, each having a more-or-less unique play style (the warrior plays sort of like the valkyrie, but I'm getting ahead of myself). I was skeptical when I heard Arrowhead were making this game; I liked Magicka, but I couldn't bring myself to play it for very long because it was quite buggy, especially the multiplayer, and the singleplayer got old partway through the game. The humor was also extremely hit-and-miss.This game has the tightness and polish that Magicka sorely needed. As many would say nowadays, this game just "feels" right. I was using a PS4 controller to play this game, and it played excellently. I have not tried the keyboard and mouse configuration, but while being a member of the "PC master race," I believe one of the PC's greatest strengths is to be able to use a wide array of peripherals -- not just keyboard and mouse. Skilled players can weave through seemingly impossible crowds of enemies, staying just out of melee range while getting into good position to use their abilities.And that's the thing I appreciate the most about this game: when you start becoming good at it, it feels quite good. This is especially noticeable with the Wizard, probably in my opinion the most powerful, but also the hardest character. Arrowhead have clearly revealed themselves to be avid D&D fans at this point; two games featuring ALL-POWERFUL MAGES AND JUST LOOK AT ALL THESE ENEMIES FALL BEFORE MY ARCANE MIGHT. Those of us who have played 3rd edition know exactly what I'm talking about, and Arrowhead made it quite explicit with the cheeky reference to Gary Gygax in the Wizard's dialogue. Other characters are no cakewalk either, but the Wizard demands that you memorize each of his spell combos before you can even begin to play him properly. It's a similar system to Magicka's spells, except you only have three elements to mix (mapped to the face buttons) and you only need to mix two at a time, resulting in far fewer unique spells than Magicka. However, they're also radically different from each other, unlike most of Magicka's spells.The Warrior can also be difficult; he is a melee powerhouse with little-to-no defense, instead relying on his brute strength to cut down enemies before he's cut down himself. He has a lot of hitpoints, but the combination of melee and no defensive actions means you'll probably get hit a lot. He is extremely efficient at killing the dreaded Summoning Stones, though, even moreso than the Wizard. I think the Warrior deals the most raw damage-per-second, if his foe stands there and takes it. In a solo game, the player will find himself using the Rush maneuver often, which allows the Warrior to charge through enemies, knocking them away like leaves to a rake. His light attack swing is very wide, which actually makes the Warrior effective when cornered, allowing him to stunlock all enemies in melee range until they die while his back is protected. This doesn't work as well in later levels, where the enemies are more varied and have more potent abilities.The Valkyrie is a master of mobility and defense, using her Spear Thrust to charge forward and deal damage, or quickly escape. She can also block with her shield at any time, rendering her invulnerable from a side. She can throw her shield like Captain America, which deals a lot of damage, and bounces between enemies as long as they're close to one another. It also hits enemies on the return path. She's possibly the most versatile character, perhaps even the easiest to solo the game with. I ended up soloing the game with the Warrior and Wizard, though.I didn't play the Elf at all beyond the tutorial, but playing him is a lot like playing a twin-stick shooter. The player uses the left stick to move and the right stick to shoot arrows like some kind of green machinegun. He also drops bombs and later gets an ability that allows him to shoot bomb arrows, and shoots powerful sniper shots (he has to be still to aim them, though).I think the biggest issue with this game would have to be the nature of the encounters; they all have the same basic setup. One or a few mage enemies support a horde of melee enemies, who all protect a Summoning Stone, which slowly summons reinforcements. This has the potential to get old, but the enemies do vary enough to keep it enjoyable. Later, the mages can channel into the Summoning Stone to have it summon faster, which might result in the player being overwhelmed if he does not kill the mage responsible.It also helps that, every other stage, the game has a "gimmick" or something to throw in the mix, just to change the levels up a bit. Don't fret when the same gimmick is used more than once early on -- they change completely later.Overall, this is quite a solid game that's worth sitting down with a few friends when you get that itchy "gotta kill 243 orcs" feeling.

												At first I was unsure about this game. It was pretty fun at least in multiplayer with 3+ players. It was short though, we burned through all of it in one "all-nighter." So I wasn't sure if it was worth the money, though I did buy the 4-pack so I could share.However, I notice today that there is a 1.5GB update and the devs have added things and changed some of the systems (seemingly for the better). This is great, I love when devs keep working on their games and adding content and changing things. Redigit (Terraria) is a great example of this. That game is the best money I have ever spent.In short, I am no longer unsure about whether this game was worth it and I'm very glad that I bought and enjoyed this game with my friends. We will probably play it again soon to see the new things and changes to old systems.

												The new slayer edition of this game pretty much made things worse overall.first off it reset my progress, doesnt matter so much if youre planning on buying but i was on the last level of the game...The game still isnt very well optimized in fact i'd say it's worse, according to the system requirements i should be able to run this game on mid-high, unfortuntely i'm chugging 15 frames on the lowest settings possible.I have an Intel i5 3rd generation proccessor, with 6gbs of ram, and a 2gb 740M  dedicated nvidia card.The respawn system previously worked very nicely in co-op, skull coins (earmed by killing enemies) would grant you a 5 second respawn time, this is still the case. however if you didnt have skull coins you could respawn, you'd just have to wait for 20 seconds and hope your friends dont die. the new respawn system makes it so that after youre out of skull coins you cant respawn anymore. This could potentially mean that in some levels (where enemies are scarce) that you could die, and not respawn to help your team mate for almost the whole level.The difficulty isnt all that difficult outside of the bosses either, the AI monsters will either swarm you or try to take you from range, with a more nimble class such as the elf or valkyrie dodging is easy unless swarmed, even at 15 FPS.they did bring some improvements into the game, namely they changed the leveling system, equipment is unlocked through coins instead of beating a game on a certain difficulty, and the health difference between a low armor class (half of the classes) to a heavy armor class (the warrior) is more apparent, however it should be said that more health really doesnt make a difference since the warrior is melee only so he will be getting beat up quite a bit. They also added some more enemies (that teleport! or maybe they just introduced old enemies sooner) but again it's pretty much attack at range or a numbers sort of thing.Overall, unless you have friends to play with and a mid-high range gaming pc this isnt worth your time. the game will take you at most 6-7 hours to beat, there's also a horde mode which is basically survive as long as possible, gets pretty boring after an hour or so since it's very repetitive.While i welcome some changes made to the game in the new slayer edition, i can't recommend this game for it's overall horrible optimization and lack of interesting game play. it's fun with friends but it wont last you very long.

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												I really wanted to like this game, but it lacks in content and unlockables.  It's also very short.  There are 3 zones, each having 3 levels and 1 boss; this amount of content feels like a beta at best.  I tried playing it a bunch of times to rekindle the love of the old Gauntlet games, but no luck, just another hack-em-up dungeon crawler that's boring as hell.  Hopefully the devs will get a clue and release more levels, unlockables, and rewards; until then, I wouldn't bother.  Or wait until it's $4.99.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
												Anyone who is a huge fan of the previous Gauntlet for the N64 is in for a real let down. When they said, "The classic Gauntlet ... returns in a completely new experience!" They weren't kidding...Character controls are completely different. Warrior and valkyrie have zero ranged attacks, while ranger and wizard owns the entire game.Warrior- Next to useless, DPS, Good timed-based attacks.Valkyrie- Infinite defence against everything besides AOE, next to useless.Ranger- Dodge skill, ranged base attacks.Wizard- Magicka-esque controlls. Combination of 3 skills for various effects. Completely steals majority of loot.Level design have zero regards for the previous Gauntlet since they're short, very boring and leave no impressions like, "Oh, remember that one time at the sand level..." Enemies are simple, spawn at regular intervals and the spawner is a sponge for damage. Enemy designs are boring and uninteresting. Little/No replay value as loot are purely cosmetic or used as a 'super.' Leveling up does nothing.

content:
Posted: November 11, 2014
												Gauntlet is a fun game ot play...but it has alot of cons to it.... for example:-If your playing with other people...you share the same screen so its fustrating when you want to go one way but u cant becuase someone else is going another way. It makes exploring the game a bit fustrating.-Looting; When you collect gold coins u all share the gold but if someone dies that person loses there pocket change. Which would also allow someone to pick it up after u drop giving that player who picked it up more money. -Classes; okay...I have to be honest....being a melee class...really sucks....Because the Wizard and the archer are the only characters that can get any kills and stay alive while the melee classes could barely get any kills in. Melee classes also die alot if they dont have any space to run back and forth to the monsters...run in, hit once...run back... thats it for melees while the ranged classes will kill everything before it even touches them. another diffrence is, melees are really good at taking spawners down...so thats a plus for being a melee...right..? not really the spawned mobs will just suround u and you'll die if your not careful. However, i would still give it a try. Expecially if you got friends you can play with.

content:
Posted: November 5, 2014
												When I saw the announcement for this I was ecstatic. My friends and I eagerly awaited release, and even when it got pushed back started guessing that they were making more content or enhancing the game.I guess in our minds it was to be Gauntlet Legends  with a retro style option (like the Sonic 2d/3d retro/modern crossover game) We were all pretty let down.The wizard controls were probably the single greatest disappointment. They render the character a punishment to a party of 4 players. The fact you can have only 1 of each class hurt too>All in all, very let down, and really hoping they patch/upgrade the game for free to rectify the short comings. Would love to see a Gauntlet game like Dark legacy brought back with procedurally generated maps, questing system, item collection, unlockable characters/classes, a leveling system with player chosen stat increases, DLC expansions, Workshop support, character appearance customization (minor would be plenty) and better character controls.If you are looking for games like this one, get Hammerwatch. It has better balance, larger maps, more classes. and the same feel graphics and mob-wise.

												This game had several issue (the biggest being performance problems) when it was released.  I really wanted to enjoy the game, but just couldn't.  The recent Slayer Edition update seems to have fixed every gripe I had with the game.  Now it is a streamlined and enjoyable experience.  They added gameplay depth  in the way of weapons that affect how your characters abilities work, the way potions work with the new talisman items, and relics being on cooldown instead of using potions.I can't really compare this game to previous Gauntlet games.  I only played the original a few times at the arcade a long time ago.  I enjoy the this game with the Slayer Edition update.To sum up:  If you played this game before Slayer Edition and were disappointed, then definitely update and try it out again.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												TLDR: $20 gets you a fun coop experience with a few bugs that need to be hashed out.  Game is not that deep, but what were you expecting from a more faithful reboot of an arcade game from 1985?  Definitely worth it if you have friends.Let's just get this out first and foremost: This is a $20 reboot of a classic arcade game.  Have you played the original arcade game in a while?  It is about as vanilla of an experience as you can get.  It could easily be described as a fantasy themed, slower paced, robotron with keys in a maze.  Am I bashing the original game?  Hell no, it's a classic and a blast - but I wouldnt call it deep.  If you are looking for a complete reimagining of the series, then stick to Dark Legends or many of the other 4 player top down / isometric cooperative games that are more modern (Diablo, Sacred 3, etc)So what do we get for our $20?  We get a much prettier 1985 Gauntlet with a few modern twists in the form of relics and perks.  Level flow is very methodical.  It's handcrafted dungeon (as per described in the trailer), procedurally generated level with some kind of theme (Death, Darkness, Lava bombs per world respectively), Arena Fight, then boss.  You can beat the game in about 3-5 hours on normal.  Honestly after beating it 2P with my wife, I have to agree that the real game shines on hard or insane with 4P.  This is where cooperation is key and little set backs (like the famed shooting the food) create that fun "tension" between the players.  We get the original 4 classes, with some significant differences between them.  The Valkarie has a defensive shield, a spear dash, and a Captain America-esque sheild throw.  She is a defensive player that can trade her best defensive skill for her best offensive skill (shield throw disables block).  The Elf has rapid fire arrows, a high powered sniper shot, and bombs (that eventually become tied to the sniper shot).  This is your low hp hit and run character with burst damage.  Then we get to the two most (appropriately in a thematic sense) opposite characters in the game - The wizard and the warrior.  The warrior is rather bland with a medium cooldown AOE attack, two basic melee attacks, and a dash with a rather long charge time.  Some of his perks seek to spice him up slightly, but it feels like he is simply not quite as unique as the remaining characters.  He needs something to stand out, and it feels like the least amount of time was devoted to fleshing him out.  He has a powerful cleave that can one shot basic enemies - but it has a small area of effect thus rendering it really only useful towards attacking spawners.  Maybe he improves with perks, but he feels initially weak - which is not the impression to make with a hulking muscle bound killing machine with a 5 foot long broad axe.The wizard on the other hand is the utility character.  Many will note that the game is made by the same team who worked on Magicka, and his spell system is very similar to a watered down version of the one found in said game.  For those accustomed to DOTA2, he is very similar to Invoker.  He has low hp, but has the most versatile skill set of the entire game.  Merlin has various forms of AOE crowd control, a teleport, and decent damage output.  He has the potential to be the single most powerful character in the game once you are practiced with switching between his nine(!) available spells.  This is entirely my opinion - but the Wizard is aboslutely brilliant and is by far the most entertaining character to play in the entire game.So, as has been noted by fellow reviewers, there are some balance issues in the game.  Some characters are simply more well rounded than others.   Some are exceedingly more complicated, but far more rewarding as well (Im looking at you Merlin).  It feels that the relic system, which allows characters to purchase special abilities that are useable via potions found in the dungeons, could have been used to balance this better - but everybody can purchase and use the same relics.  It may sound restrictive in a sense, but perhaps it would have been best to allow only certain characters to purchase certain relics.  Especially in the case of the very vanilla warrior and the overly versatile wizard.  There are some definite bugs as well - Crypts (World 1) 1-2 has a reoccuring bug where doors will not open or keys will not spawn.  I've encountered this bug at least 3-4 times, and it forced us to restart the level to progress.  My wife and I have experienced crashing issues.  There are issues selecting resolutions in the graphical settings and the game doesnt play especially friendly with dual monitor configurations.  Some players are noting GPU overheating issues when vsync is disabled as well.Overall, however, I felt the need to write this review because I am sincerely enjoying the game.  It really shines with 4 players on hard or insane, but is a fun romp even on normal with 2 players.  I feel the price is perfectly acceptable for the amount of content this game provides, as well as the ability to play it online or couch coop.  If you approach the game with the expectations of what it really is - a more faithful remake of an arcade classic - then I am sure you will not be disappointed.

												Absolutely amazing game. Highly recommended if you're a fan of the classic Gauntlet games from both the 80's and the more modern era (Gauntlet Legends in the arcade and N64 come to mind) I personally found it was very very similar to Gauntlet Legends with the top down perspective being slightly different but nonetheless welcoming. Overall I'd give it a 4/5 5 being if it was actually possible to get new weapons rather than have to rely on relics which takes potions to power to boost your character.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
												So I put about 5 hours into this game. Safe to say it is a quick hack n slash with really no story line. The only replay value is playing through with each character buying their respected gear and leveling up what gear you can.  I had bought this on sale with the DLC and played through with the necromancer on normal and I think I died once, maybe twice throughout the entire game and then I got destroyed by the last boss having to battle him around 10 times to finally kill him. There weren't really any puzzles. Just follow the path, hack n slash and that's about it. There is some occasional voice dialogues but nothing special. I believe there could have been a lot more added to this game but since I got it on sale I feel like I got what I paid for which was around 5 bucks. If I had paid full price I would of been extremely dissapointed. I understand the dev's wanting to keep it similar to the classics but that was 15 years ago. We need more and a lot has changed with gammers needing certain things to keep the replay value up like skill trees and character leveling. Otherwise you play through once and then uninstall.Would I recommend this game? Sure. Its a quick hack n slash. Is there replay value? Afar from playing with different characters there is no replay value in my personal opinion so I suggest getting it on sale because that is how much it's really worth in play value.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												It is the Gauntlet name, theme, and characters, but it just didn't "feel" like gauntlet to me.  The static top-down view and other major differences in the game cause me not to get that nostalgic Gaunlet feel that I was looking for.  Don't get me wrong, the game itself is enjoyable.  I played one character (Wizard) through most of the game, but I honestly don't know if I would play through it again.  There are just too many differences.1. While  the characters may be the same, their abilities are different entirely. For example: Wizard, while challening and fun, has its own skill system by combining two elements to come up with 9 different unique attacks.  That has nothing to do with the original Gauntlet game for consoles / arcade.2. The storyline and levels are completely different.  If anything, it now feels more like a cross between old school Diablo and Magicka.  3. Character progression is awkward.  Instead of leveling up, in this game you can get mastery levels that provide certain bonuses to that character.  This is similar to an "achievement" system, where for example you kill 1,000 enemies with fire spells you get a 5% cooldown reduction on one of your fire skills.  The damage doesn't change, just the cooldown.  I miss the idea of just leveling up like the original Guantlet!  They could have had an achievement system, which is usually a great idea; but tieing it into character progression hurt the game in my opinion.4. The Magic Potions are more or less removed from the game.  Instead of a potion you can throw out to kill everything on the screen, you now use "potions" as currency for using one of your two equippable artifacts that all have their own abilities.  While I like the artifacts, I would have enjoyed them so much more if they had their own charges and potions were still something in the game.  When you see this game's version of "Death" in some levels, you can't use a magic potion (or anything else for that matter) to get rid of him.  You just keep running away until he goes away.All in all, the game is decently fun to play.  Not a blow-you-away-amazing kind of game, but it's a good little time sink.  Unfortunately though, I do have to caution that this really isn't "Gauntlet" in anything but name.  It isn't going to give you that nostalgic feel that you expect, so you will have to look eslewhere for that.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Pure dungeon crawling - you and up to 3 other players take on the Gauntlet, a giant magical labyrinth summoned by the powerful wizard Morak. You control your character (there are for - the heavy hitting warrior, the quick and defensive Valkyrie, the Wizard who deals in a large number of spells, and the Elf archer) from a bird's eye perspective, killing monsters and picking up loot. The eventual objective is to find 3 amulets and give them to Morak for power unimaginable.The graphics are reasonably good looking without interfering too much with the gameplay - a plethora of effects add a splash of colour to a game that is otherwise somewhat dull (greys n browns). You'll be too busy paying attention to the horde of mummies running after you to really pay that much attention. The view distance is also high enough that you don't really need to worry much about fine details. Music is a simple background melody encouraging you to keep on hacking and slashing - as for effects, monsters grunt, missiles bounce off the valkyrie's shield with a DINK and the wizard spells zap and boom entertainingly. Voice acting is rather lacklustre but is hardly an integral part of the game.From a control perspective, each character has their own set of light attacks, heavy attacks and special abilities - the wizard using a 2 button combo system to cast a wide variety of spells from 3 elements (storm, earth and fire). The response on both gamepad and Keyboard/Mouse is good, with minimal delays in the character doing what you want. The game does feel like it lacks a bit of variety - the problem with being a faithful remake is that after a little while things start to get a bit samey, but adding a friend or two to the mix can bring up the replay value immensely. There's even an element of competitiveness as the game tracks how much gold you obtain and how many kills you make, as well as a "crown" that can be taken off monsters each level to give a single player a significant bonus. Watching a group of people chase after a shiny hat while more and more mummies pop out of the ground is amusing, to say the least.Overall, Gauntlet takes a simple concept and does it well. It's definitely a good match for Diablo or Torchlight players, even though there is minimal progression aside from upgrading your relics and masteries (which provide minor bonuses) the game has few lulls and keeps your attention through constant, unrelenting action.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												First off.. this is a well executed game. It is much like the original Gauntlet (which I spent too much money on) It's very loyal to the original game. The original is one of the first true multiplayer experiences (way back in prehistory) And I think this is an excellent game to gather some friends, have something to drink and play together for a while. It is a hack and slash fest, just like Diablo, but unlike the latter, this doesn't take itself seriously. Now, the praises aside, it does have a few minor chinks in it's armour. Multiplayer invites doesn't work properly. For some (at least for me) unfathomable reason, you need to have the friends window open, so to see the invite, that upon clicking it.. will launch the multiplayer properly. How they thought *that* was a good idea, I'll never understand (and I should probably point the finger at Steam, since more games have this peculiar behavior) The second is that you can't click past the intial tutorials.. I find that very very annoying! But still, it is a fun and enjoyable game, but I am not certain of the longevity. EDIT: I cleaned up the review a little, and shortened it. But the essentials are the same.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												A decent remake. Though, it strays from the path of traditional gauntlet games somehow. They added plenty of great aspects like character progression and you can purchase "relics" that help out quite a bit. But somewhere down the line it just doesn't quite feel like gauntlet should in my opinion. I remember Gauntlet Dark Legacy and Gauntlet for the Nintendo Entertainment System/Famicom Gauntlet for the NES had tons of random exit portals that would take you from a golden treasure ladden world to having monsters rushing you from the gate. Dark Legacy brought personality to the game through numerous unlockable characters and plenty of diversity through the "color" of your character to bring specific properties to your magic and special attacks not to mention the terrific voice acting for its time. where those games excelled this game really falls short. The levels are pretty linear and predicatable and the voices and personalities of the characters are pretty awful. My review is mixed due to the fact I was simply expecting more. It's a great time with friends and local co-op is always a welcome addition to any of my PC games. I'd give it a solid 6/10 for gameplay until any DLC for characters or a more arcade like experience. And a very low 3/10 for the voices. I have more personality in my sleep than my poor Elf does any time.  I Recommend this game only because despite its flaws it is entertaining and for the 15 dollars I paid for it it's a welcome addition to my library, especially if I have friends over.

												A very good game that you can easily sink quite a few hours into. The gameplay is simple and each class/character feels distinct. Each character has very few skills, but the game has yet to become repetitive. The game used to give you power increases for completing objectives as each character essentially ranking up that character, but that has been removed. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Is this a great game? Yes.Is this a great Gauntlet game? Not really.I might be blinded by nostalgia (this is a nostalgia review) but, Gauntlet Legend on N64 forged in my mind what a Gauntlet game should be. Then, I got Gauntlet Dark Legacy on GameCube and the game kept everything I loved in the N64 version and added a crazy amount of content.Sadly, this game went away from a lot of element I loved about the past 3D Gauntlet. From what I played so far, it did bring some new interesting ideas, but sadly it got rid of a lot of what I consider the "core" of Gauntlet. In this state, it felt a bit more like a clone of Diablo 3.-- Improvement from previous Gauntlets --- Small puzzle to make the game feel a bit less repetitive. (Sadly they do reuse the same kind of puzzle a bit too often)- Actions like grabbing an explosive barrel. (Didn't like that the barrel could respawn)- Achievements to upgrade your hero.- Boss that require more thinking to kill effectively.- The potion use for the special ability is a great mechanic.- Unique way to play each type of hero.-- What is missing from previous Gauntlets --- Collectible! Where are my runes?- A lively overworld. (It does look really dull without theme levels)- Not a fan of the new way enemy portals works. (My biggest complaint)- No levelling up! (I did love the level grind when I was to weak for some boss)- No easy way to upgrade what your hero needs. (Strength / Speed / Armor / Magic)- Don't like how often you need to kill all enemies in a room to open gates.- Keys are too static and don't give the player much choices. (I miss these trap chest! haha)-- TLDR --Overall, if you like the dungeon crawling style in general, for the price, this is a great game.On the other hand, if you expect something like Gauntlet Legends or Gauntlet Dark Legacy, you might be disappointed.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												I loved Gauntlet, it's probably one of the strongest memories I have of playing arcade games with mates and this is a really polished reimagining of one of my childhood classics.The title theme has nods back to the original theme, the original four characters are there (with vocals this time). They play a little differently, no longer bound by just one attack, a change I'm still on the fence about. The Wizard for example works very much like a cut-down version of a Magicka character, pressing two button combinations to change the attack to Chain Lightning or a force push-back or a fire-bomb or a charge attack that turns you into twin fireballs that set enemies alight.The little nods back to the original are a nice touch and the combat is still as frenetic as I remember. There is even a classic mode which turns the graphics back to grubby 8-bit, currently made popular by all the dogshit indie games.I feel a bit down that the people who I used to play real Gauntlet with back in the day are not really gamers anymore because I think they would love this as much as I do.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Perfectly done, this reload of an old classic does not disappoint! It really feels like the old arcade hit and you get into trouble when the hordes are coming. The addition of relics and mastery give this title a bit of longterm replayability. Co-op is loads of fun and it's much better than Gauntlet: Dark Legacy. Even the price is ok, 20 Euro as launching price is more than fair. If you're a fan of the original, this is a must. All who are looking for a fun co-op game, just get a four pack of this and you'll be playing the whole night... and many more nights.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												I am going to be honest.  The game itself is short.  Does not take too long to play through the entire game.  The upgrades don't do much but give you different looking stuff, not that there is anything wrong with cosmetic upgrades.  Relics are a nice touch and give players a life line when they are in serious trouble.  I would recommend playing the game on normal to start with as at higher difficulties enemis spawn quicker and become tougher which is hard to deal with when first starting out.  The actual character upgrades come from achievements completed throughout the game, death being part of those achievements.  I played through the game with a wizard and I would STRONGLY suggest to play with a controller and not a keyboard and mouse, it is very much designed with controllers in mind.  Wizard works in an interesting way where you press a combination of buttons to set a certain spell to attack with.  Each spell having a different range and bringing different benefits with it.  Each floor is setup in three stages: Exploration, escape/run for your life, and Survival (in that order).  It can become repetative and nothing really changes through different playthroughs.  All of this said, it is still an enjoyable experience.  The kind of joy that comes from taking hordes of monsters head on and coming out of it victorious.  It is still very much a Gauntlet game in its roots.  Fight large hordes, pillage all the loot, look for keys, and eat some of that sweet sweet food.  If afters reading this you have reservations about the price then I would wait a while until it goes on sale but I do suggest that at some point you give it a try because I believe it is worth your time.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												A major point that others have made that I do not agree with:"Faithful to the original."It's not all that faithful really! Other than the same 4 player characters the game is different in major ways.1st, the maps are always the same (though I might have not played enough yet to see if this is true). In the original, other than a few maps like the first one, the maps are random generated so you often have the challenge of finding your way through the dungeon.2nd, all the characters in the original were able to use the potions to a lesser effect than the wizzard. So far in my time playing I have been unable to use any of the collected potions on either the elf or the warrior, what's the point of collecting them?3rd, in the original you were able to kill the Death enemy using said potions!4th, you are unable to change characters when you die. The original, as long as there is another player in the game alive, you could switch class of character before resurrection. In Gauntlet 2 you could even choose a character that is already playing, leading to quotes of "Green elf shot at food" and "Yellow warrior is about to die!"And 5th, missing a fun feature of the second Gauntlet (again I might not have played enough to verify this fully): The game of "It" (or "Tag" for Americans). Best in team play because when a special enemy when killed, the player who killed it becomes 'it' and all the enemies flock towards them. They have to stay alive of course and try to tag another player to make them 'it'. Was such fun running round trying to avoid the enemies and tag my brothers :PAnother minor issue is that others have said the game is polished and well made. I guess they missed the fact the character animation is not properly matched to the speed of movement, they kind of look like they are running on a slightly icy surface! (It’s more noticeable with the characters where you can see the legs). But hey, it's a minor issue as I said :)Despite all those points above I would still recommend this game on its own merits. It looks great and is much fun to play. It's not a faithful modern remake of the originals but it a great modern sequel to them :)

												While it has a handful of baffling limitations, this iteration of Gauntlet is super fun to play, and that's what matters.Playing with a friend or two (or three!), I had a blast getting through the first section of the game. That said, the game looks great even on the lowest settings.I'd love to be able to drop in and out of games, at the discretion of the person hosting the game.If the host drops, the game out to pass on to another player, making them the host.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Gauntlet 2014 harkens back to the good old days of coin munching arcade games. It's fairly faithful to the original with the 4 classes; Warrior, Valkyrie, Wizard and Elf (why isn't this guy called Archer?), shooting food, grabbing gold and fighting over the crown for high scores at the end of each level.The game's a ton of fun and easy to pick up and play but hard to master. It's a little light on content at the moment. 3 distinct areas each with 4 levels comprised of 3 floors each. The last level is a boss for 3 total. I expect there to be DLC for new levels in the future. I highly recommend this game for couch co-op fun. Be ready to punch your friends when they steal the crown or shoot the food when you're low hp! At $20.00 (or $15.00 at GMG) it's an easy purchase.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												You know I absolutely LOVED the arcade and N64 versions of Gauntlet so I'm bias as far as that goes but I really have to say that day one bugs really turn me off.  Strike one for this company was the ungodly frustrating bugs in Magicka.  This is strike two for Arrowhead Game Studios and if the Gauntlet bugs aren't seriously addressed in later releases, they've lost a customer for life.FAIR WARNING:  I'm writing this review with 1.6hrs of gameplay under my belt so draw your own conclusions on what I noticed during my brief time.  In complete honesty, after the game crashed 1.6hrs in, I didn't bother loading it up again and played Civ 5 instead.  I'm really irked about my ill-Magicka feelings bleeding through onto this review, but that's what happens when you don't address defects in your software.Pros: Nostalgia, graphics, puzzle environment, online multiplayer, levels load very fast.Cons: oh boy, here we go...-Full screen video.  The game start with your windows start bar displaying.  You can change it to full screen but the full screen setting doesn't always stick.-Games in Progress:  You can't join (or have your friends join) a game that has already started. Highly annoying.-Character Selection: You can't select more than one character type at the same time.  i.e. you can't have four warriors at the same time.  You should be able to have a red/blue/green/yellow warrior but you no can haz!-Upon death: I would love to have the ability to change character classes but since I'm locked to one class once I join the game, I can't do that.-The camera.  I played with two other players and all of us were on the same half of the screen, yet, the camera doesn't move to compensate unless you touch the edge of the screen.  This leads you to burn up keys that you've collected.-Auto Fire:  When using the mouse, you can hold the left click to auto-fire with the archer, but none of the other characters have an auto-fire ability.  This leads to insane amounts of clicking and can get really tiresome.  I haven't tested this with my USB Logitech selectable auto-fire controller but I'm going to be forced to use it if this feature doesn't get added.-Buggy:  Random crashes reminiscent of Magicka that turned you off to Magicka in the first place.  I was lucky enough to get to unlock level 4 with two of my friends in one sitting before the first crash occurred.-Collision:  Collision should be an option to be turned on or off.  It's upsetting when your friend blocks a doorway and you die because can't get past him.-Random spawn timers:  I've died and have had to wait anywhere from 5 seconds to 20 seconds to spawn and have no idea why the timers are different.-Wizard:  The gameplay is challenging enough as it is, and your character is already always on the move dodging enemies, so why introduce "Magicka style" 3 or 4 button combinations needed to cast a magic spell?  It's my opinion that the wizard will be the least used character because of this.-Warrior and Valkyrie:  The HP attributes on these two characters needs to be improved, either that or make the fighting space a lot larger, have have the baddies do less damage, or introduce a slight knock back on every attack.Hopefully these issues will be addressed in future updates.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Is this a great game? Yes.Is this a great Gauntlet game? Not really.I might be blinded by nostalgia (this is a nostalgia review) but, Gauntlet Legend on N64 forged in my mind what a Gauntlet game should be. Then, I got Gauntlet Dark Legacy on GameCube and the game kept everything I loved in the N64 version and added a crazy amount of content.Sadly, this game went away from a lot of element I loved about the past 3D Gauntlet. From what I played so far, it did bring some new interesting ideas, but sadly it got rid of a lot of what I consider the "core" of Gauntlet. In this state, it felt a bit more like a clone of Diablo 3.-- Improvement from previous Gauntlets --- Small puzzle to make the game feel a bit less repetitive. (Sadly they do reuse the same kind of puzzle a bit too often)- Actions like grabbing an explosive barrel. (Didn't like that the barrel could respawn)- Achievements to upgrade your hero.- Boss that require more thinking to kill effectively.- The potion use for the special ability is a great mechanic.- Unique way to play each type of hero.-- What is missing from previous Gauntlets --- Collectible! Where are my runes?- A lively overworld. (It does look really dull without theme levels)- Not a fan of the new way enemy portals works. (My biggest complaint)- No levelling up! (I did love the level grind when I was to weak for some boss)- No easy way to upgrade what your hero needs. (Strength / Speed / Armor / Magic)- Don't like how often you need to kill all enemies in a room to open gates.- Keys are too static and don't give the player much choices. (I miss these trap chest! haha)-- TLDR --Overall, if you like the dungeon crawling style in general, for the price, this is a great game.On the other hand, if you expect something like Gauntlet Legends or Gauntlet Dark Legacy, you might be disappointed.

content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												I loved Gauntlet, it's probably one of the strongest memories I have of playing arcade games with mates and this is a really polished reimagining of one of my childhood classics.The title theme has nods back to the original theme, the original four characters are there (with vocals this time). They play a little differently, no longer bound by just one attack, a change I'm still on the fence about. The Wizard for example works very much like a cut-down version of a Magicka character, pressing two button combinations to change the attack to Chain Lightning or a force push-back or a fire-bomb or a charge attack that turns you into twin fireballs that set enemies alight.The little nods back to the original are a nice touch and the combat is still as frenetic as I remember. There is even a classic mode which turns the graphics back to grubby 8-bit, currently made popular by all the dogshit indie games.I feel a bit down that the people who I used to play real Gauntlet with back in the day are not really gamers anymore because I think they would love this as much as I do.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												This is something of a Marmite game - you either love it or hate it. There's some very justifiable criticism out there but in some cases at least I think it's down to people's expectations.For me, this is all about nostalgia for those of us who remember pumping 10p coins into the arcade machine. It'd be a hoot playing with friends too. It reproduces the spirit of the original Gauntlet in an updated game.That means that the negative points are all correct. Yes, it's simplistic; you shoot stuff and collect gold. No character development, no massive story, it's all in the instant gratification of hurling firepower at suicidal enemies and watching them drop like flies. It's the kind of game you can pick up, blast for ten minutes and put down with a grin.Other bad points are harder to justify. It's very, very short for starters - only twelve levels which you'll clear in a few hours on the normal difficulty. The writeup claims "randomly generated levels", implying (again, maybe only for those old enough to remember) a massive variety of semi-randomised levels once the twelve designed ones are dispensed with. Sadly, this just isn't true. There are twelve levels, full stop. Some people claim that one or two levels might be partly random but one of those is a "darkness" level, where you can only see a short distance from your character, so it's difficult to tell because most of the screen is just black. And if it's difficult to tell, it might as well not be random. If it is, which I doubt.At present you can't change the key bindings if you don't have or like the gamepad. And since the best control scheme is "WAXD" and not, as the world seems to incorrectly believe, "WASD", that's a real pain. Maybe I just have unnaturally short thumbs.Final gripe: un-sodding-skippable chuffing cut scenes! The final level (that's number twelve, in case you missed the "short" comments above) is, not surprisingly, a boss battle. You're gonna die. Lots. And every time you do, you have to sit through the same. God-damn. Cutscene. It's not a five-second intro either, we're talking the best part of a minute to cool your heels after narrowly being smooshed in mid-lunge towards the food. I went postal on the gamepad after the first half-dozen times and after that, the monologuing wizard went silent in all later replays. Maybe he was embarrassed. He still acted the part out though. In full. Every time.Do I recommend it? Yes - it looks good, controls well (with a gamepad at least), and most importantly of all it recaptures the feel of the original. It desperately needs more places to explore though, at least as randomly-generated maps. Much better would be a Steam Workshop tie-in.Gauntlet needs level editor. Badly.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												TLDR: $20 gets you a fun coop experience with a few bugs that need to be hashed out.  Game is not that deep, but what were you expecting from a more faithful reboot of an arcade game from 1985?  Definitely worth it if you have friends.Let's just get this out first and foremost: This is a $20 reboot of a classic arcade game.  Have you played the original arcade game in a while?  It is about as vanilla of an experience as you can get.  It could easily be described as a fantasy themed, slower paced, robotron with keys in a maze.  Am I bashing the original game?  Hell no, it's a classic and a blast - but I wouldnt call it deep.  If you are looking for a complete reimagining of the series, then stick to Dark Legends or many of the other 4 player top down / isometric cooperative games that are more modern (Diablo, Sacred 3, etc)So what do we get for our $20?  We get a much prettier 1985 Gauntlet with a few modern twists in the form of relics and perks.  Level flow is very methodical.  It's handcrafted dungeon (as per described in the trailer), procedurally generated level with some kind of theme (Death, Darkness, Lava bombs per world respectively), Arena Fight, then boss.  You can beat the game in about 3-5 hours on normal.  Honestly after beating it 2P with my wife, I have to agree that the real game shines on hard or insane with 4P.  This is where cooperation is key and little set backs (like the famed shooting the food) create that fun "tension" between the players.  We get the original 4 classes, with some significant differences between them.  The Valkarie has a defensive shield, a spear dash, and a Captain America-esque sheild throw.  She is a defensive player that can trade her best defensive skill for her best offensive skill (shield throw disables block).  The Elf has rapid fire arrows, a high powered sniper shot, and bombs (that eventually become tied to the sniper shot).  This is your low hp hit and run character with burst damage.  Then we get to the two most (appropriately in a thematic sense) opposite characters in the game - The wizard and the warrior.  The warrior is rather bland with a medium cooldown AOE attack, two basic melee attacks, and a dash with a rather long charge time.  Some of his perks seek to spice him up slightly, but it feels like he is simply not quite as unique as the remaining characters.  He needs something to stand out, and it feels like the least amount of time was devoted to fleshing him out.  He has a powerful cleave that can one shot basic enemies - but it has a small area of effect thus rendering it really only useful towards attacking spawners.  Maybe he improves with perks, but he feels initially weak - which is not the impression to make with a hulking muscle bound killing machine with a 5 foot long broad axe.The wizard on the other hand is the utility character.  Many will note that the game is made by the same team who worked on Magicka, and his spell system is very similar to a watered down version of the one found in said game.  For those accustomed to DOTA2, he is very similar to Invoker.  He has low hp, but has the most versatile skill set of the entire game.  Merlin has various forms of AOE crowd control, a teleport, and decent damage output.  He has the potential to be the single most powerful character in the game once you are practiced with switching between his nine(!) available spells.  This is entirely my opinion - but the Wizard is aboslutely brilliant and is by far the most entertaining character to play in the entire game.So, as has been noted by fellow reviewers, there are some balance issues in the game.  Some characters are simply more well rounded than others.   Some are exceedingly more complicated, but far more rewarding as well (Im looking at you Merlin).  It feels that the relic system, which allows characters to purchase special abilities that are useable via potions found in the dungeons, could have been used to balance this better - but everybody can purchase and use the same relics.  It may sound restrictive in a sense, but perhaps it would have been best to allow only certain characters to purchase certain relics.  Especially in the case of the very vanilla warrior and the overly versatile wizard.  There are some definite bugs as well - Crypts (World 1) 1-2 has a reoccuring bug where doors will not open or keys will not spawn.  I've encountered this bug at least 3-4 times, and it forced us to restart the level to progress.  My wife and I have experienced crashing issues.  There are issues selecting resolutions in the graphical settings and the game doesnt play especially friendly with dual monitor configurations.  Some players are noting GPU overheating issues when vsync is disabled as well.Overall, however, I felt the need to write this review because I am sincerely enjoying the game.  It really shines with 4 players on hard or insane, but is a fun romp even on normal with 2 players.  I feel the price is perfectly acceptable for the amount of content this game provides, as well as the ability to play it online or couch coop.  If you approach the game with the expectations of what it really is - a more faithful remake of an arcade classic - then I am sure you will not be disappointed.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												Pros: Some great co-op action for fans of Gauntlet and for people who just want a dungeon crawler where they can smash stuff. Provides a good challenge, especially on harder difficulties.Controls work decently well on mouse and keyboards.Game is good, simple fun. Blowing up a huge group of enemies with a well timed bomb or whirlwind is insanely satisfying. Cons: Balance issues. At the moment, the classes don't feel very balanced, especially the warrior who feels underpowered compared to the other 3 classes. The default controls work well, but there doesn't seem to be a way to rebind them, which some people might not like.No drop-in multiplayer, party has to be formed before starting.Can only have one of each class per game, so there can't be multiple warriors or valkyries, etc. This is slightly problematic because gold, unlocks, and masteries are tied to character. So you can end up being forced to play on a character that you have nothing unlocked on if the role is already chosen.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												I am going to be honest.  The game itself is short.  Does not take too long to play through the entire game.  The upgrades don't do much but give you different looking stuff, not that there is anything wrong with cosmetic upgrades.  Relics are a nice touch and give players a life line when they are in serious trouble.  I would recommend playing the game on normal to start with as at higher difficulties enemis spawn quicker and become tougher which is hard to deal with when first starting out.  The actual character upgrades come from achievements completed throughout the game, death being part of those achievements.  I played through the game with a wizard and I would STRONGLY suggest to play with a controller and not a keyboard and mouse, it is very much designed with controllers in mind.  Wizard works in an interesting way where you press a combination of buttons to set a certain spell to attack with.  Each spell having a different range and bringing different benefits with it.  Each floor is setup in three stages: Exploration, escape/run for your life, and Survival (in that order).  It can become repetative and nothing really changes through different playthroughs.  All of this said, it is still an enjoyable experience.  The kind of joy that comes from taking hordes of monsters head on and coming out of it victorious.  It is still very much a Gauntlet game in its roots.  Fight large hordes, pillage all the loot, look for keys, and eat some of that sweet sweet food.  If afters reading this you have reservations about the price then I would wait a while until it goes on sale but I do suggest that at some point you give it a try because I believe it is worth your time.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												TL;DR version: Gauntlet  is good.The new Gauntlet game on steam is delightfully fun. Each character has a very unique play style. The levels are all well designed, with little to no down time in the action. The game flows pretty smoothly, and the inclusion of local multiplayer means you can have your friends over, pop on some usb controllers and have a great time together.A few friends and I beat the game last night, after about 6-8 hours of play. At $20, that's about what I was expecting for completion time. There is a decent amount of replay with the challenges, and the unlockables.The story was very minimalistic, not a lot to it. Which can be expected from a title in the Gauntlet series.The character customization leaves a lot to yearn for. There are different clothing items and weapons you can wear, that are aesthetics only. There are relics that you can equip to compliment your playstyle, but they aren't game breaking on their own.Graphics are smooth, run well, and have a few options that allow this to work well on older computers. It also has a 'classic' filter you can apply to the game that puts a layer of pixelization over the game. It's a fun throwback, but makes aiming ranged attacks difficult, and can make it hard to differentiate between certain enemies.All in all I'd rate this game highly mostly for the nostalgia factor. 7.5/10. Best if played with friends.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2014
												The, purposefully encouraged, backstabbing of the original is all still intact (you can loot an ally’s corpse, so shooting food so they can’t heal themselves now has a very tangible reward) and Arrowhead clearly have a genuine fondness for the original game, but they – like so many before them – have failed to find a way to make it relevant for the modern era.In Short: It’s certainly not the worst Gauntlet revamp there’s ever been, but there’s too little substance or variety to satisfy either new fans or old.Pros: The characters have been sensibly updated and there’s a clear love of the original evident throughout. With four committed players the co-op works well.Cons: Repetitive and overly simplistic, and that’s even ignoring there’s only three worlds. Awkward camera and interface, bland visuals and enemies, and uninteresting upgrade system.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
												First off.. this is a well executed game. It is much like the original Gauntlet (which I spent too much money on) It's very loyal to the original game. The original is one of the first true multiplayer experiences (way back in prehistory) And I think this is an excellent game to gather some friends, have something to drink and play together for a while. It is a hack and slash fest, just like Diablo, but unlike the latter, this doesn't take itself seriously. Now, the praises aside, it does have a few minor chinks in it's armour. Multiplayer invites doesn't work properly. For some (at least for me) unfathomable reason, you need to have the friends window open, so to see the invite, that upon clicking it.. will launch the multiplayer properly. How they thought *that* was a good idea, I'll never understand (and I should probably point the finger at Steam, since more games have this peculiar behavior) The second is that you can't click past the intial tutorials.. I find that very very annoying! But still, it is a fun and enjoyable game, but I am not certain of the longevity. EDIT: I cleaned up the review a little, and shortened it. But the essentials are the same.

content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Gauntlet 2014 harkens back to the good old days of coin munching arcade games. It's fairly faithful to the original with the 4 classes; Warrior, Valkyrie, Wizard and Elf (why isn't this guy called Archer?), shooting food, grabbing gold and fighting over the crown for high scores at the end of each level.The game's a ton of fun and easy to pick up and play but hard to master. It's a little light on content at the moment. 3 distinct areas each with 4 levels comprised of 3 floors each. The last level is a boss for 3 total. I expect there to be DLC for new levels in the future. I highly recommend this game for couch co-op fun. Be ready to punch your friends when they steal the crown or shoot the food when you're low hp! At $20.00 (or $15.00 at GMG) it's an easy purchase.

												I bought the 4-pack because I was desparate to get my kids onto something other than Minecraft.  It worked, for a little bit anyway.  But, for me, I was happily tickling my completionist bone until 1.1 landed.  New character, you say?  Sweet!  $5 more?  Um, well... okay, I guess... it is a fun game, so sure!  Completely massacre my masteries so as to render them effectively useless against the onslaught, and deliver a one-two punch knock-out to my ability to enjoy the game solo?  No thanks.  Hard and Unfair were already challenges, and now they're outright impossible.  Damage from the Wizard, across the board, has been rendered so ineffective, that creatures spawn faster than they can be put down, even with the strongest spell cycles.  I feel like I was bait and switched.Look, Arrowhead, I appreciate new stuff, and don't even mind buying it... but if it ain't broke, don't fix it.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 19, 2014
												It is the Gauntlet name, theme, and characters, but it just didn't "feel" like gauntlet to me.  The static top-down view and other major differences in the game cause me not to get that nostalgic Gaunlet feel that I was looking for.  Don't get me wrong, the game itself is enjoyable.  I played one character (Wizard) through most of the game, but I honestly don't know if I would play through it again.  There are just too many differences.1. While  the characters may be the same, their abilities are different entirely. For example: Wizard, while challening and fun, has its own skill system by combining two elements to come up with 9 different unique attacks.  That has nothing to do with the original Gauntlet game for consoles / arcade.2. The storyline and levels are completely different.  If anything, it now feels more like a cross between old school Diablo and Magicka.  3. Character progression is awkward.  Instead of leveling up, in this game you can get mastery levels that provide certain bonuses to that character.  This is similar to an "achievement" system, where for example you kill 1,000 enemies with fire spells you get a 5% cooldown reduction on one of your fire skills.  The damage doesn't change, just the cooldown.  I miss the idea of just leveling up like the original Guantlet!  They could have had an achievement system, which is usually a great idea; but tieing it into character progression hurt the game in my opinion.4. The Magic Potions are more or less removed from the game.  Instead of a potion you can throw out to kill everything on the screen, you now use "potions" as currency for using one of your two equippable artifacts that all have their own abilities.  While I like the artifacts, I would have enjoyed them so much more if they had their own charges and potions were still something in the game.  When you see this game's version of "Death" in some levels, you can't use a magic potion (or anything else for that matter) to get rid of him.  You just keep running away until he goes away.All in all, the game is decently fun to play.  Not a blow-you-away-amazing kind of game, but it's a good little time sink.  Unfortunately though, I do have to caution that this really isn't "Gauntlet" in anything but name.  It isn't going to give you that nostalgic feel that you expect, so you will have to look eslewhere for that.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 27, 2014
												Gauntlet returns in glory, bringing in a lot of co-op fun.You play as either Elf, Wizard, Warrior or Valkyria.Elf - a constant barrage of ranged damage, special skill is a bomb that does AoE damage.Warrior - Warrior flies on a magic carpet, with a sniper rifle and rocket launcher as a special skill.No. Warrior hacks and slashes. What did you expect? His special is even more hacking and slashing.Valkyria - Less offensive than warrior, seconadary attack is actually a shield block instead, special allows for a more flexible attack.Wizard - Has a lot of different spells, so it kind of feels like few classes cramed into one. Has supportive spells, variety of offensive spells from long range, medium or close. Is is the most difficult class, but overall can be most usefull as well.Game only offers 12 stages of varying length (3 of those are boss battles, that are rather short). You can play those on Easy, Medium, Hard and Very Hard modes. Those were balanced quite well. I mean, hard IS hard.The difficulty raises with more players present. Playing alone can quickly get boring, but playing with a team of 4 randoms usually turns into frantic running.For me it feels the best to play with 4 players that you know or 2 when joining/hosting randomly - that way it is easy to coordinate and share stuff between players, even without any form of communication inside the game.You can unlock a variety of items and upgrade them up to 3 levels. They give additional skills (up to 2 at a time) but those need potion pickups to be used. In 4 player team, that will be quite rare.The game can be finished in 3-4 hours, but it is meant to be replayed a lot.Overall, it can get boring over time, unless more areas (DLCs?) arrive.7.5/10 would be my score. Not saying the game is bad, it just feels small... In size, vision, length. Otherwise it delivers a lot of fun and I can recommend it. Old school to the bone :)

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
												Perhaps you bought this thinking, hey, Gauntlet, that game was great to play with friends on the NES. And hey, Gauntlet Dark Legacy, that game was awesome too. So you may think, hey, another Gauntlet game, it's been years since Dark Legacy, surely this one will be even better. You'd think that, and you'd be WWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWWRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRRROOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOONNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNNGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGGG.Instead they decided to make this garbage. This 1.79 GB bloated shovelware that indicates they got lazy and made this in some game making program instead of a real programming language that actually deserves to be on Steam. All that space surely isn't being taken by the music that some high schooler who downloaded a MIDI program wrote. Nor the extremely repetetive level layouts. Or was it just bloated on purpose because nobody would take a 50MB game seriously?Finally, what's with the videos showing 4 people playing? It is impossible to find a single other person playing this no matter how long you wait to find other players. I would have an easier time going to various game stores, finding one that has the old PS2 Gauntlet Dark Legacy, then knocking on random people's doors asking, "hey, you want to play Gauntlet Dark Legacy", until someone says "yes, as long as it doesn't suck as much as that terrbile Gauntlet for PC game", and taking them to my place and playing it, than it would be to find someone who actually wants to play this online.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												Though I was very excited about the game I have to say that on a variety of levels it is sadly a disappointment. Play is generally pretty flat, single-player is mostly unengaging, multi-player is often more frustrating than exciting, and there simply isn't enough variation in play to make it compelling. Perhaps it is unfair to expect it to have more in common with Diablo but when it is flat even compared to clones a mere modern version of the arcade classic lacks depth or interest. I'd even say console titles like Dark Legacy were probably more engaging, just something is missing, perhaps patches or something will make it work better.

content:
Posted: October 27, 2016
												If you're expecting a remake to the original arcade Gauntlet,(video below) I recomend this game.


YouTube™ Video: Gauntlet - Arcade 

			Views: 253,087		

			Gauntlet (c) 12/1985 Atari Games. Up to four players take on the role of either Elf, Valkyrie, Wizard or Warrior in this classic Dungeons & Dragons-inspired shoot-em-up.		

If you're expecting a Gauntlet Dark Legacy remake,(video below) I don't recommend this game.


YouTube™ Video: Gauntlet Dark Legacy (PS2) 

			Views: 33,142		

			Technically sold as an expansion to Gauntlet Legends, Dark Legacy could be called more of an enhanced remake to the 1999 arcade hit than a sequel.		

If you're new to Gauntlet I recommend it. It's a fun laid back coop game. It's not trying to be the next Diablo. Gauntlet has always been about smashing through waves of enemies down endless dungeons with other people. Grabbing all the gold and not shooting the food. Only one copy needed for couch coop.

												The game is great, especially with friends, but I've had several problems- first, when playing online, I've been kicked out for various reasons, whether appcrash or some other magic, when I've returned, everything is gone. Expect more slaughtering than puzzles.  Haven't tried the necormancer yet, not sure if I'll bother purchasing the character.  Some classes like wizard I suggest only using with friends as they are extremely vulnerable by themselves.

In other words: either you play this game for hundreds of hours, killsteal like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, or you spend a lot of time solo.

content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												We were looking for a co-op game to play with out of town family, and when we found Gauntlet it was the perfect fit.  This was a casual game that we could play once a week for an evening, and something that even my (non-gamer) wife could, and did, enjoy with us.  The game was short, but even after completing it we could mix up the characters that we played or increase the masteries of our favorite class.  This was our favorite game.When we saw that the game had been given some love, we looked forward to a little polishing and even hoped for additional levels.  Unfortunately, what we got was some graphics polishing that added odd stutter and erratic movements to the display, deterioration of the camera control, and the removal of the RPG element of character advancement through the abilities improved through masteries.  Worse of all for our players was the elimination of “endless lives” when in a group (easy and normal difficulty prior to the patch), which had allowed the most casual to enjoy the game; those players are no longer interested in playing.  So, please bring this back in some form, maybe just to the easy difficulty level, or as an option in the game setup for the host (these scores do not need to be included in the leaderboards – some of us just want to allow more people to enjoy the game and not just try to game the high score). Sadly, I can no longer recommend this game.

Feels good to be back!When you enjoyed this game on your C64 and in arcades back in the day, Gauntlet is for you. The game mechanics(fight demons, find gold and keys, get through the maze) of the original have been nicely polished and ported to the present, while the classic top-down viewmodel was kept. The online multiplayer seems to be dead by now, but it is still possible to play multiplayer locally.This makes Gauntlet a nice party game(e.g. for Halloween).

number of helpful: 5 of 12 people (42%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 2, 2014
												I'm old enough to have played the original Gauntlet arcade game, back in ~1985. This new steam version, is based on that, rather than the newer versions that came out in the 1990's.I never liked the original arcade game. The repetition of spamming the fire button, while you fed the machine quarters, to increase your slowly, yet inevitably draining life, never appealed to me. I loved the music and digitized speech though. Arrowhead, the developers of this new game also created the game, Majicka. I found the demo of Majicka mediocre.I do love this new version of Gauntlet. Let me start with the negatives:- There is no lobby chat, in-game chat or world chat. There's no chat period. It is strange, noticeable and frustrating.- The game is not properly integrated into Steam, so there's no way to add players that you played with. Social networking is a pain and something that is done in the community hub.- The game will randomly disconnect you from a game, due to some kind of flaw in the networking code. The game does have a "rushed-out-the-door" feeling to it.- Some people who played the game on easy or normal complain at the "lack of content", since they finished the game in 3 - 7 hours. I have only only ever played the game on Hard and Unfair.- A couple of days ago, I saw my first hacker. The game had high score hacks, on day zero. That did not matter to me. However, I recently played with a warrior, with no cooldown on his abilities, which is a huge cheat! A friend also saw a valkyrie using an infinite health hack. I'm seeing more people talking about hackers in the community forum and I think that eventually, this game might end up the same way that Max Payne 3 multiplayer did ( overrun by hackers ). I don't think that developers care about hackers, to be honest ( they got their money ). Somebody mentioned on the forum, that saves are client side, therefore hacks were inevitable:{LINK REMOVED}http://www.cheathappens.com/20352-PC-Gauntlet_cheats


YouTube™ Video: Gauntlet Trainer +3 Cheat Happens 

			Views: 7,777		

			http://www.cheathappens.com/20352-PC-Gauntlet_cheats • Unlimited Health • No Attack Cooldown • Add/Reset Gold Gauntlet Cheats Gauntlet Trainer Gauntlet Cheat Codes Gauntlet 2014 Cheats Gauntlet 2014...		

- The population is rapidly dropping to less than 3,000 players, from a peak of 12,669:http://steamcharts.com/app/258970#Allhttp://steamgraph.net/index.php?action=graph&appid=258970The positives:- I love the challenging combat and AI on Hard and Unfair. The melee characters are fairly basic. Warrior has a heavy cleave attack, a 360 degree spin attack and dash, which knocks over enemies. Valkyrie has: a spear thrust; a shield defence, that renders her immune to attacks; a shield throw, where she uses her shield as a killer frisbee ( like in the 1980's movie, Krull ). Elf is a dynamic bowman that can tumble, drop bombs and snipe at long ranges. He can also attach bombs to his arrows, which is an excellent game mechanic. Wizard, my favourite character, has to juggle 9 spells: light fireball, heavy fireball, teleportation, spherical shield, ice freeze, area effect ice slow, short range electric shotgun arc, long range electric shock. Wizard alone, makes having an XBOX controller for PC, a must.- I love the orchestral music, which seems to change depending on what is going on in the environment.- I really enjoy the level design. I think that a lot of thought was put into the aesthetics. There's a stereotypical temple setting, a scary, cavernous, spider crypt and a fiery, lava realm.Value:Using a level 49 Wizard, I have solod the harder realms, on the hardest difficulty level. There are about 10 levels per realm, for a total of roughly 30 levels. The developers could have added another 3 - 6 realms but at the same time, the game was available for $20 and through trading, I actually paid $10. It's hard to say how much value you will get out of the game because it depends on what difficulty level you play and which, ( if any ) characters appeal to you. I enjoy playing the valkyrie, elf and wizard. I find the warrior painfully boring but will play him occasionally.

content:
Posted: September 23, 2014
												Well the wait is over, does the game live up to expectations?  So far I've played Elf and am enjoying it a ton.  Here are the positives:+Sound design is excellent+monters are tough but not too tough, challenging+instances are well thought out+menu screen is simple to navigate+tons of achievements ingame that actually help you progress+graphics and gameplay are smooth as butter even with tons of stuff happening+fun coop so far, but I have only played once with a friend but so far so good!+background music is very good, voice overs by classes and protagonist are all good+secret areas to discover, some puzzles, monsters have different abilities and different game modesAnd now the negatvies:-NO ABILITY TO REBIND CONTROLLER OR KEYBOARD?  W - T - F1. Elf light shot is bound to RS which is OK but why not trigger?  Or give us the option to swap stuff around2. Other classes have same issue though least annoying is Valkyre and Thor**I cannot believe, in this day and age of consumers demanding certain things as given and standard NO ability to rebind anything is going to really annoy many people.  What if you were left handed using a controller?  What if, you just wanted to have Light Attack on a trigger rather than a button.  This speak of LAZY design, they even pushed the game back to give more time to finish things up.  I can only hope they patch this in later.  -Unbalanced characters:1.  Thor has no evasive moves, typically a meat shield will have a dodge or a shield or something, he only has Bull Rush which in most instances is useless.2.  Merlin has no defensive skills that can be used conveniantly, have discovered a lightning shield but with a long cooldown makes him very weak and hard to play.3.  Elf seems the easiest to play as auto attack, AOE bomb as well as dodge whenever he wants makes him very easy.4.  Valkyre is good but you need to keep pressure up and use her charge ability but once that is mastered you're good to go.  To sum up:  Single Player Merlin:  Very weak defensively, strong damage.Thor:  Weak defensively, average damageElf:  Excellant damage and with his dodge very good defensivelyValkyre:  Good damage and can have Average/Good defense if you use aggression properly*The player abilities may work better as a team in coop, these are my opionions from first runs through with classes.I recommend this game, IF you can get past not being able to rebind your keys - we need to, as a community raise a big stink about this one!  I do recommend the game though, it is fun as hell despite this rather major shortfall.My 0.02 cents.  Back to monster killing!  :-)

content:
Posted: March 12
												If Gauntlet was the original hack and slash game, this is a very poor cosplay of it. Warner Brothers, while famous as a movie studio, are not well known for (publishing) good games. (Arrowhead Games Studio developed it.) They say that when you go to a pizza place, don't order the salad because it's not their specialty and will probably be terrible.(03.18.17) To expand on my initial comments, if you're looking for better, similiar style gameplay to this version of the Gauntlet, I  recommend you check out Torchlight II. This (Arrowhead Games Studio developed) Gaunlet changes too much from the other more playable versions, and is a bit of a mess on the PC. It doesn't take very long playing it to recognize how much they changed the Guantlet formula. In my opinion, the previous publishers (Atari, Tengen, and Midway Games) all did a much better job.EDIT: From a comment, "Arrowhead Game Studios made this game. WB just published it." My revised review makes note of that.
